(a) No license shall be issued under this article which will entitle any person who is a law enforcement agent of any branch of government to engage in, or derive remuneration or profit from, any business herein covered. (b) No employees or elected officials of the city may be issued a license or have any interest whatsoever in such license except as may be specifically approved by the city council when such interest can be shown to pose no conflict of interest or interference with performance of official duties. (Ord. No. 2004-04-12, § III, 4-12-2004; Ord. No. 2010-12-13, § III(C), 12-13-2010) Sec. 4-30. - Licensing a firm. If the application for an alcoholic beverage license is for a sole proprietorship, the proprietor shall be qualified to obtain a license. If the application is for a business operated by a partnership, all members of the partnership shall be qualified to obtain a license. If the application is for a corporation, all stockholders owning at least 25 percent of the corporate stock must qualify. Each proprietor, partner or 25 percent stockholder shall submit to fingerprinting and investigation, and shall sign a release to obtain information. It shall be the responsibility of the business entity to make determination that the manager physically present on the business premises on a regular basis is of legal age, of good moral character, a citizen of the United States, and that said manager abides by the applicable provisions of this article. (Ord. No. 2004-04-12, § III, 4-12-2004; Ord. No. 2010-12-13, § III(D), 12-13-2010) Sec. 4-31. - New license on existing license location. To obtain a new license at an existing license location, an applicant must produce the written agreement of the existing licensee to surrender the existing license. For issuance of such new license, the applicant must meet and comply with all requirements of the ordinance which relate to approval of an original application. (Ord. No. 2004-04-12, § III, 4-12-2004; Ord. No. 2010-12-13, § III(E), 12-13-2010) Sec. 4-32. - Time limit for purchase of license; commencement of business; non-use. (a) All licenses, for which approval has been granted by the city council, must be purchased within 45 days of said approval. If license is not obtained within the 45 days, the approved application shall become null and void. The requirement also applies to approved applications for purposed locations (where construction has not commenced or is incomplete) and renovating locations (where renovation is incomplete), noting that in those instances, however, and upon purchase of the license, the license shall be held by the city council until completion of the construction or renovation of the premises of the applicant, as well as, the fulfillment by the applicant of any stated conditions of licensure, including, but not limited to, the issuance of a certificate of occupancy from the county department of community development and verification of compliance with the distance requirements of this article. (b) Failure to open the establishment within six months after the issuance of said license shall serve as the automatic forfeiture and cancellation of said license, and no refund of the license fee shall be made to the license holder. (c) Any holder of a license hereunder who shall begin the operation of the business authorized in the license, but who shall for a period of six consecutive months thereafter cease to operate the business as authorized in said license, shall, upon expiration of such six-month period, automatically forfeit such license, which license shall, by virtue to such failure to operate, be canceled without the necessity of any further action by the city council, and no refund of the license fee shall be made to the licensee. (Ord. No. 2004-04-12, § III, 4-12-2004; Ord. No. 2010-12-13, § III(F), 12-13-2010) Sec. 4-33. - Waiting period following disapproval of previous application. The city council shall not approve the issuance of any alcoholic beverage license to any applicant who applies for a license within a period of one year from the date of disapproval of a previous application for a license. (Ord. No. 2004-04-12, § III, 4-12-2004; Ord. No. 2010-12-13, § III(G), 12-13-2010) Sec. 4-34. - Parks/recreation areas. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, give away, drink, or possess any alcoholic beverages upon any of the parks and recreation areas owned by the city or the county. (Ord. No. 2004-04-12, § III, 4-12-2004; Ord. No. 2010-12-13, § III(H), 12-13-2010) Sec. 4-35. - Consumption outside alcoholic beverage establishment. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to allow persons to gather outside the premises of an alcoholic beverage establishment (e.g., parking lots) and consume alcoholic beverages. It shall be prohibited for customers of alcoholic beverage establishments to gather outside said establishments and consume alcoholic beverages. The penalty for violation of this law will be determined by title 16 of the state codes. (Ord. No. 2004-04-12, § III, 4-12-2004; Ord. No. 2010-12-13, § III(I), 12-13-2010) Sec. 4-36. - Type of beverage sales. Malt beverages and wines sold in the city may be for on-premises or off-premises consumption. (Ord. No. 2004-04-12, § III, 4-12-2004; Ord. No. 2010-12-13, § III(J), 12-13-2010) Sec. 4-37. - Occupational tax certificate. Proof of a current and valid certificate of occupational tax issued to a business/applicant must be provided prior to the issuance of an alcohol license approved by the city council. (Ord. No. 2004-04-12, § III, 4-12-2004; Ord. No. 2010-12-13, § III(K), 12-13-2010) Sec. 4-38. - Certificate of occupancy. For proposed locations and renovating locations, proof of a certificate of occupancy must be provided prior to the issuance of an alcohol license approved by the city council. (Ord. No. 2004-04-12, § III, 4-12-2004; Ord. No. 2010-12-13, § III(L), 12-13-2010) Sec. 4-39. - Food permit. Proof of a valid/current food permit issued to a business/applicant must be provided prior to the issuance of an on-premises alcohol license approved by the city council. (Ord. No. 2004-04-12, § III, 4-12-2004; Ord. No. 2010-12-13, § III(M), 12-13-2010) Sec. 4-40. - License categories and fees; purchase. (a) Categories; fees. The alcoholic beverage licenses which may be issued under this article are provided below. A schedule of annual fees for such licenses is set by the city council and maintained in the office of the city clerk. The schedule for current fees will be changed from time to time upon adoption of a resolution by the city council at a regularly scheduled meeting. Each alcoholic beverage license bears a sole and separate license fee. (1) Wholesale liquor. (2) Wholesale malt beverage. (3) Wholesale wine. (4) Retail off-premises liquor. (5) Retail off-premises malt beverage. (6) Retail off-premises wine. (7) Retail on-premises liquor. (8) Retail on-premises malt beverage. (9) Retail on-premises wine. (10) In-room service liquor. (11) In-room service malt beverage. (12) In-room service wine. (13) Liquor retail (package store). (14) Concessionaire (available only to licensees who have acquired a retail on-premises and/or a retail off-premises license for malt beverages and/or wine). (b) Purchase of license. (1) The applicant for an alcoholic beverage license shall pay to the city, at the time the license is issued, the annual license fee for operation for one year, or pay part of the year, beginning on January 1 each year, and ending on December 31 each year; with the exception that each license initially issued during the last six months of the year will be prorated, as follows: a. July through September: One-half the annual fee. b. October through December: One-fourth the annual fee. (2) The suspension or revocation of any license shall not entitle the licensee to a return of any portion of the license fee. (Ord. No. 2004-04-12, § IV, 4-12-2004; Ord. No. 2010-12-13, § IV, 12-13-2010) Sec. 4-41. - Wholesale licensing. (a) Licensing by state. All wholesale dealers or distributors shall be licensed by the state department of revenue and shall comply with all laws and regulations of such department before they sell or deliver any alcoholic beverages in the city. Deliveries and sales shall be made only to retailers licensed under the provisions of this article, and all deliveries shall be made in conveyances owned and operated by such wholesale dealers or distributors. (b) Licensee shall hold no other alcoholic beverage license. No person who has any direct financial interest in a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages at wholesale shall hold any other license or have an interest in any other license issued under the terms of this article. (Ord. No. 2004-04-12, § V, 4-12-2004; Ord. No. 2010-12-13, § IV, 12-13-2010) Sec. 4-42. - Retail on-premises licensing. (a) Licensing for restaurant/pubs/cafes only. Retail on-premises licenses for the sale or distribution of malt beverages, wine, or liquor for consumption on-premises may be issued only to the owner of a restaurant, pub, or cafe as defined in this chapter, and which has been issued a food service permit by the county health department to dispense food and drink, and has been issued a certificate of occupancy from the county department of community development to open the business to the general public. (b) Adequate parking. Adequate parking will be provided as set forth in section 4-1. All locations which do not meet the parking requirements for the issuance of a new license, but which, nevertheless, were operating with a valid license issued prior to the requirements for parking imposed by this article, are, despite the requirements of this article, eligible for the re-issuance of a similar license if application therefor is made by the same licensee at the time renewal applications are due under the terms of this article. (c) Unlawful to remove beverage from premises. An on-premises license does not authorize the holder to sell or otherwise provide or make available any alcoholic beverage for removal from the premises and it is the on-premises licensee's responsibility to take such commercially reasonable steps necessary to ensure that no beverages sold or otherwise provided by the licensee are carried off the premises by customers. The appropriate license must be obtained for each type of transaction. (d) In-room service. In-room service licenses will be issued only in conjunction with the appropriate retail on-premises licenses. All in-room service licenses are subject to all restrictions and limitations in this article relative to the sale of alcoholic beverages, except as provided otherwise in this article, and shall be authorized only on such days and only during such hours as the sale of alcoholic beverages is otherwise authorized in the city. Distilled spirits shall not be sold in packages containing less than 200 milliliters each. (e) Consumption in back room. The sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption by persons in any back room or side room which is not open to general public use is prohibited, except that private parties or conventions which have been scheduled in advance may be served in public or private dining rooms or meeting rooms, and provided further that this prohibition shall not apply to private clubs hereunder nor to the sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption hereunder to the registered guests of any hotel or motel in their designated rooms. (f) Sale in bottles. Licensees shall not permit the sale of liquors by the bottle or package, but wines or malt beverages may be sold by the bottle for on-premises consumption. (g) Sale of alcoholic beverages for reduced prices. All on-premises licensees are prohibited from selling or giving away alcoholic beverages under the following circumstances: (1) Serving multiple drinks for a single price or offering all you can drink for a set price during a set time. (2) Making a single price the basis for a required purchase of two or more servings. (3) Selling or furnishing alcoholic beverages during specified hours at a price lower than the normal retail cost. (h) Brown-bagging. No brown-bagging licenses shall be issued. No licensee possessing a license for the sale of beer or wine for on-premises consumption shall allow or permit persons, patrons, or customers to bring or keep alcoholic beverages, whether beer, wine or distilled spirits, on the premises for use or consumption thereon. (i) Time of sale. No licensee, employee of such licensee, or any person acting on behalf of such licensee shall furnish, or give alcoholic beverages to any person on any day or at any time when sale of same is prohibited by law. (Ord. No. 2004-04-12, § VI, 4-12-2004; Ord. No. 2010-12-13, § VI, 12-13-2010) Sec. 4-43. - Retail off-premises licensing. (a) Retail establishments with off-premises license; unlawful to consume beverage on-premises. It shall be unlawful for any person to consume any alcoholic beverage on any premises licensed for the sale of package liquor, beer, or wine for consumption off-premises, and it shall be unlawful for any licensee to permit the consumption of alcoholic beverages on said premises. (b) Adequate parking. Adequate parking will be provided as set forth in section 4-1. All locations which do not meet the parking requirements for the issuance of a new license, but which, nevertheless, were operating with a valid license issued prior to requirements for parking imposed by this article, are, despite the requirements of this article, eligible for re-issuance of a similar license if application therefor is made by the same licensee at the time renewal applications are due under the terms of this article. (Ord. No. 2004-04-12, § VII, 4-12-2004; Ord. No. 2010-12-13, § VII, 12-13-2010) Sec. 4-44. - Qualifications of applicants. (a) Age; character; resident. No person shall be granted a license to engage in the sale of alcoholic beverages within the city unless it shall appear to the satisfaction of the city council that such person is of legal age, of good moral character, a resident of the state, and meets all other conditions cited in this article. (b) No conviction or violation of law. The licensee shall not have been convicted nor shall have taken or entered a plea of nolo contendere, within ten years immediately prior to the filing of such application, for any felony, or any violation of the laws of this state or any other state. Where the violation is for a misdemeanor, forfeiture of a bond, violation of a county or municipal ordinance, or where there is a plea of nolo contendere, the city council, after investigation, may waive such conviction as a disqualification. (Ord. No. 2004-04-12, § VIII, 4-12-2004; Ord. No. 2010-12-13, § VIII, 12-13-2010) Sec. 4-45. - Application for licensing. (a) Contents of application. All applicants for alcoholic beverage licenses shall complete, sign, and have notarized, an application form prescribed by the city council that shall contain all necessary information, data, and records pertinent to the determination of the qualifications of the applicants. Failure to furnish such data shall automatically serve to dismiss, with prejudice, the application. (b) Investigation/processing fee. Upon filing of the application with the city council, the applicant shall deposit, in cash or certified check, a processing fee to be established by the city council, from time to time to cover the expense of investigation of the applicant, and processing the application, which fee shall not be refundable. A copy of the completed application shall be furnished to the county sheriff's department, community development department, health department, and the city police chief. Redactions will be used as necessary. (c) Fingerprinting and data check by sheriff's department. The applicant for an alcoholic beverage license shall submit to fingerprinting and will sign a release form for the release of his information. An applicant's qualifications shall be checked by the sheriff's department. (d) Signs posted. (1) Business location. An applicant will cause to be placed upon the location of the business proposed for the sale of alcoholic beverages a sign or signs, stating the following: NOTICE Alcoholic Beverage License Applied for. Type of License: ____________ Name of Applicant: ____________ First Reading Date: ____________ Second Reading Date: ____________ Location: City of Hamilton, Georgia (2) New building. Where no building is erected at a location proposed for the sale of alcoholic beverages, the applicant shall cause to be placed upon the location a sign, stating the following: NOTICE Alcoholic Beverage License applied for. Proposed Building No: ____________ Street: ____________ Type of License: ____________ Name of Applicant: ____________ First Reading: ____________ Second Reading: ____________ Location: City of Hamilton, Georgia (3) Notification. After the departmental recommendation process, as stipulated in subsection (e) of this section, has been completed, the applicant will be notified to appear in the city hall office within 24 hours to obtain said sign. A nonrefundable fee to be determined by the city council, from time to time shall be charged for said sign, the fee for which shall be included on the schedule of annual fees for alcohol licenses set by the city council, and which shall be changed from time to time upon adoption of a resolution by the city council at a regularly called meeting. (4) Sign size. The sign shall be 24 inches by 30 inches, with black lettering on a white background, and shall be placed within 15 feet of the right-of-way of the street upon which said proposed building or existing business fronts, and shall be easily seen from all public streets, alleys, sidewalks, or other public property adjoining the location. (5) Sign installation. The sign shall be erected on or within 24 hours of the date the sign is issued to the applicant. Said sign shall remain up continuously during the pendency of the application and shall be removed within ten days after such application is acted upon by the city council. The sign erected pursuant to the provisions hereof shall contain no additional advertisement or words other than that which is specified herein. (e) Recommendation of approval or disapproval by city police department. The city chief of police must sign each application and indicate his recommendation for approval or disapproval of said application, based upon the investigation of the applicant. An official of the county health department must sign all applications for on-premises licenses and indicate his recommendation for approval or disapproval of said application, based upon whether or not the applicant has obtained the necessary food service permit. (f) Readings of applications. No application for a license hereunder shall be acted upon by the city council until two readings have been held during two consecutive regularly-scheduled meetings of the city council. (Ord. No. 2004-04-12, § IX, 4-12-2004; Ord. No. 2010-12-13, § IX, 12-13-2010) Sec. 4-46. - Appeal of denial of license. Any applicant to whom a license is denied shall have the right to request a hearing before the city council, such request to be filed in writing within 30 days of the date of the denial. The city council shall set the date, time and place of the hearing and shall hear the appeal with the right of the applicant to appear in person or by counsel and present evidence and be heard thereon. After such hearing, the city council shall make such decision as it deems appropriate, and the decision thus made shall be final and binding. Pending appeal from the city council, the applicant shall not have the right to carry on such business. (Ord. No. 2004-04-12, § X, 4-12-2004; Ord. No. 2010-12-13, § X, 12-13-2010) Sec. 4-47. - Transfers of licenses. (a) Change in ownership of business. Transfer of license shall not be allowed where there is a change in the ownership of a business. In such case, the new owner shall file an application as for a new license as provided by this article. (b) Change of location of licensed business. A license may not be transferred from one location to another, even temporarily, and there shall be no utilization of an existing license by a licensee at a new business location. Any change in business location will require the filing of an application as for a new license as provided by this article. (Ord. No. 2004-04-12, § XI, 4-12-2004; Ord. No. 2010-12-13, § XI, 12-13-2010) Sec. 4-48. - License renewals. (a) Annual renewal date. All license renewals under this article shall be applied for and the fee paid for on or before November 15 of the current license year. Renewals after November 15 shall pay, in addition to the regular fee, a penalty of ten percent before such license shall be issued. Licenses shall expire if renewals are not applied for, and renewal fees plus any penalties are not paid in full, on or before December 31. Such expired licenses shall not be renewed unless the licensee reapplies and follows the application process set forth herein for new applicants. (b) Disapproval of renewal. Except as otherwise provided in this article, no license shall be renewed where the licensee commits any act in violation of federal, state, or local laws, or where any other act or condition would disqualify an original application. (Ord. No. 2004-04-12, § XII, 4-12-2004; Ord. No. 2010-12-13, § XII, 12-13-2010) Sec. 4-49. - Restrictions/responsibilities of licensee; general. (a) Responsibility of conduct of employees. The licensee is charged with the responsibility for compliance with this article by his employees, officers, agents, or servers while in his employment. (b) Employment of minors. (1) No licensee shall allow or require a person in his employment under 21 years of age to dispense, serve, sell, deliver, possess, or take orders for any alcoholic beverages for consumption on-premises. (2) Persons under 18 years of age employed, and working in a supermarket, convenience store or drug store of a licensee holding an off-premises consumption license are not prohibited from selling or handling alcoholic beverages which are sold by the licensee for consumption off-premises. (c) Sales to intoxicated or rowdy persons. No licensee hereunder shall sell alcoholic beverages to any person in an intoxicated condition, and it shall be the responsibility of the licensee or his employees to enforce this section. Further, it shall be the duty of all the licensees and their employees in such places of business to keep their premises clear of all persons who are intoxicated, rowdy, or noisy, and who do anything to disturb the peace. (d) Display of license and signs. (1) The license issued under this article shall be posted in a conspicuous place in full view of the public. (2) The holder of a license to sell alcoholic beverages shall post in the most conspicuous place signs provided by the state relative to sales of alcoholic beverages to persons under the age of 21 years of age. (3) All dealers who sell at retail any alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises shall post, in a conspicuous place, a sign provided by the state which reads: "WARNING: DRINKING ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES DURING PREGNANCY CAN CAUSE BIRTH DEFECTS." (Ord. No. 2004-04-12, § XIII, 4-12-2004; Ord. No. 2010-12-13, § XIII, 12-13-2010) Sec. 4-50. - Hours of operation of licensee. (a) Legal hours. The legal hours of operation for the sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages by a licensee within the city shall be between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 2:00 a.m., Monday through Friday; and from 6:00 a.m. to 12:00 midnight on Saturday. (b) Sunday sales. There shall be no alcoholic beverages sold, distributed or otherwise made available within the city on Sundays. (c) Election day sales. Pursuant to the authority granted by O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20, the sale by wholesale and retail of alcoholic beverages shall be lawful during the polling hours of any election; however, nothing in this subsection shall authorize the sale of alcoholic beverages within 250 feet of a polling place during such time as the polls are open. (Ord. No. 2004-04-12, § XIV, 4-12-2004; Ord. No. 2010-12-13, § XIV, 12-13-2010; Ord. of 6-31-2012) Sec. 4-51. - Suspension and revocation of license. (a) Grounds. (1) Omission/concealment/misstatement in application. Any material omission, false or misleading information, misstatement, or concealment of fact in the initial application or renewal of license shall be grounds for the denial of a license; and if any license has previously been granted under such circumstances, the same shall constitute grounds for revocation of the license issued, and shall make the applicant liable to prosecution for false swearing under the law of the state. (2) Violation of federal, state or local laws. Any violation of the provisions of this article by a licensee or his employees, servers, officers or agents, or violation of any federal, state, or local laws or ordinances which would disqualify a person from obtaining a license, shall be grounds for revocation or suspension of the licensee by the city council pursuant to that procedure as set out in subsection (b) of this section, excepting those situations as stated in subsection (c) of this section. Such violation of this article shall constitute a misdemeanor wherein the offender, upon being found guilty, shall be punishable as for a misdemeanor, and/or as specified by the laws of the state and rules of the state department of revenue. If such act, omission or violation is done by an agent, server, employee or officer of the licensee, the lack of knowledge on the part of the licensee or the lack of authorization for such act or omission or violation shall be no defense. (3) Moral turpitude. The entry of a plea of guilty or nolo contendere, or the conviction of any licensee with respect to a charge in violation of any federal, state, or local laws relating to alcohol control, or any crime, whether a felony or not, involving moral turpitude. (4) Failure to pay fee or tax. Failure of a wholesaler or retailer to pay a license fee or pay required excise tax. (5) State revocation of license. When any state alcoholic beverage license is revoked by the commissioner of the state department of revenue, any similar license issued to the same licensee by the city shall be automatically revoked without any further action by the city council or any officer of the city. (b) Procedure. (1) Notice to licensee of hearing. Notice shall be given to the holder of a license at least seven days in advance that the city council will hear a recommendation that the license be suspended for a definite period of time, or revoked, and this notice shall include the specific grounds on which this recommendation to the council will be made. The city clerk will be responsible to notify the license holder as to the time that the recommendation for suspension or revocation will be heard. (2) Hearing. The city council shall hear the recommendation for suspension or revocation at one of its regularly scheduled meetings, at which time the holder of a license, his counsel, and any other interested parties will be heard. The holder of a license shall have the right to present evidence under oath, introduce documentary evidence, and cross-examine witnesses. (3) Suspension/revocation by majority vote of the city council. The decision, by a majority of the city council present at the meeting, to suspend or revoke an alcoholic beverage license, shall be made immediately following the hearing. (4) No refund when license suspended or revoked. When a license is suspended or revoked, the city shall not be required to refund any portion of the license fee to the holder of such suspended or revoked license. (c) Exception to general procedure for suspension and revocation of license. (1) Summary suspension. If the city council or the city police chief find that the public health, safety or welfare imperatively requires emergency action and incorporates a finding to that effect in an order, summary suspension of a license may be ordered pending proceedings for revocation, suspension, or other action, which proceeding shall be promptly instituted and determined. In such instances, the licensee shall be furnished the specific grounds for the summary suspension in writing and provided same at least seven days prior to the scheduled hearing. (2) Recommendation to the city council. Immediately following the summary suspension of a license, the chief of police shall forward a written report to the city council regarding said suspension, and shall recommend action to be taken by the council, e.g., suspension for a definite period of time, or revocation of the license. (3) Certificate of occupational tax. Failure to maintain a current certificate of occupational tax for the establishment for which an alcoholic beverage license has been issued will result in the suspension of the alcoholic beverage license until such time as evidence of a valid/current certificate of occupational tax is provided to the office of the city council. (d) Time limit for issuing new license after revocation. When a license has been revoked under the provisions of this article, no application for a new alcoholic beverage license for the same location will be received for a period of 12 months from the effective date of revocation, and no application for a new license from the licensee shall be received for a period of 24 months from the effective date of revocation. (Ord. No. 2004-04-12, § XV, 4-12-2004; Ord. No. 2010-12-13, § XV, 12-13-2010) Sec. 4-52. - Motion for rehearing. In the event a license is suspended or revoked by the city council, the licensee may file a motion for a rehearing of the decision of the council with the council's office, in writing, within 15 days from the date of the council's decision, and shall outline the manner in which such protestant believes the city council erred. If the motion relates to a matter in which evidence has already been heard, it is discretionary with the city council as to whether to grant the motion for rehearing. If the substance of the complaint made was not the subject of a prior hearing at which the protestant was permitted to be present and heard, the city council shall afford a hearing within 15 working days after the filing of the motion, of which reasonable notice shall be given to all parties known to the city council to be interested. Persons interested in protesting or supporting the action of the city council shall be allowed to appear, be represented, and introduce oral and documentary evidence, and examine and cross-examine witnesses. (Ord. No. 2004-04-12, § XVI, 4-12-2004; Ord. No. 2010-12-13, § XVI, 12-13-2010) Secs. 4-53—4-77. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - OPEN CONTAINERS
Sec. 4-78. - Possession of open container prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession any alcoholic beverages in any open container while on the public streets, sidewalks, rights-of-way or in any public or semi-public parking facilities within the corporate limits of the city. (Ord. No. 12-10-90, § 1, 12-10-1990; Ord. No. 2013-10-14-D, § C, 10-14-2013) Sec. 4-79. - Possession in automobiles prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession any alcoholic beverages in any open container while an occupant of any motor vehicle, whether such vehicle is underway or not, while such vehicle is on the public streets, sidewalks or rights-of-way, or in any public or semi-public parking facility within the corporate limits of the city. An open container shall be considered to be in the possession of a passenger if it is not located in a locked glove compartment, locked trunk or other locked non-passenger area of the vehicle. (Ord. No. 2013-10-14-D, § D, 10-14-2013) Sec. 4-80. - Application of section 4-79 to passengers of limousines, buses and campers. Section 4-79 shall not apply to: (1) A passenger of a limousine or other similar vehicle pursuant to a contract to provide transportation for hire, and such driver holds a valid commercial driver's license pursuant to state law or that of any other state. (2) A passenger of a bus in which the driver holds a valid commercial driver's license pursuant to state law or that of any other state. (3) The occupants of the living quarters of a camper or motor home. (Ord. No. 2013-10-14-D, § E, 10-14-2013) Sec. 4-81. - Posting of notice by establishments. All premises licensed for the sale of alcoholic beverages within the corporate limits of the city are hereby required to post in a conspicuous location inside such establishment a notice informing patrons that open containers are prohibited on the public streets, sidewalks, rights-of-way or in any public or semi-public parking facility within the city. (Ord. No. 2013-10-14-D, § F, 10-14-2013) Sec. 4-82. - Penalty. Any person, firm or corporation violating any provisions of this article shall be fined according to the penalties described in the general provisions chapter of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed to have been committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. No. 2013-10-14-D, § G, 10-14-2013)

div.head: Chapter 6 - ANIMALS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Livestock running at large or straying, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-1 et seq.; permitting dogs in heat to roam or run free, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-6; Responsible Dog Ownership Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.; Georgia Animal Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq.; control of rabies, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-1 et seq.; cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4; liability of owner or keeper of vicious or dangerous animal for injuries caused by animal, O.C.G.A. § 51-2-7.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 6-1. - Provisions incorporated by reference. The animal control ordinance of the county, currently codified as chapter 5, article III in the Harris County Code, is adopted by this reference and incorporated in this chapter and made a part of this Code in as full and complete a manner and with like effect as though set out in full in this section. Sec. 6-2. - Public nuisance animals. (a) The harboring of any animal found to be dangerous or a public nuisance is hereby prohibited. (b) The classification of a dangerous or public nuisance animal will be determined by the county animal control officer under the existing intergovernmental agreement between the city and the county. (Ord. No. 2006-11-13, § 1, 11-13-2006; Ord. No. 2015-11-10, § 1, 12-14-2015) Sec. 6-3. - Penalties. Any person who shall violate the provisions of this article, upon conviction, shall be subject to a penalty according to the penalties described in the general provisions chapter of this Code. Any designated representative of the city police department, county animal control officer, or the county sheriff's department may enforce the provisions of this article. All fines so assessed shall be recovered for use of the city through the municipal court. (Ord. No. 2006-11-13, § 3, 11-13-2006) Secs. 6-4—6-24. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - DOGS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Responsible Dog Ownership Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.
Sec. 6-25. - Responsibility of owner to keep dog under control by leash or confinement. Dogs in the city are required to be penned up, fenced in, chained, or otherwise confined to the premises of the owner or, if off the premises of the owner, must be leashed and under the immediate control of the owner. If any dog shall be at large and not on a leash and under the immediate control of the owner thereof, the owner of the property on which any such dog running at large may enter may take such action to remove such dog as is reasonable under the circumstances. (Ord. No. 90-4-9, § 1, 4-9-1990) Secs. 6-26—6-53. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - LIVESTOCK[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Livestock running at large or straying, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-1 et seq.
Sec. 6-54. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Livestock means domestic animals and fowl customarily kept on a farm including, but not limited to, horses, mules, donkeys, cattle, sheep, goats, ducks, geese, chickens, and turkeys. (Ord. No. 2006-11-13, § 1, 11-13-2006; Ord. No. 2015-11-10, § 2(A), 12-14-2015) Sec. 6-55. - Space requirements. No livestock shall be permitted on a lot containing less than four acres. On lots greater than four and less than ten acres, there shall be allowed one livestock animal per acre, or its portion. For lots in excess of ten acres, there shall be no restriction as to the number of livestock animals allowed. (Ord. No. 2006-11-13, § 1, 11-13-2006; Ord. No. 2015-11-10, § 2(B), 12-14-2015) Sec. 6-56. - Proximity to property lines. On any lot upon which livestock are lawfully kept as allowed in this section, all such livestock shall be kept at least 50 feet from any property line. (Ord. No. 2006-11-13, § 1, 11-13-2006; Ord. No. 2015-11-10, § 2(C), 12-14-2015)

div.head: Chapter 8 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Authority to adopt technical codes, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(12); state minimum standard codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20(9)(B)(i); enforcement of minimum state construction codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26; construction standards generally, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-1 et seq.
Sec. 8-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this chapter shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Building official or building inspector means the qualified building official or qualified building inspector as designated by the city. Dwelling, as used in this chapter, shall mean a structural dwelling house built of wood, rock, or ceramic materials or of any other accepted materials used in construction of buildings, modular homes, trailers, and pre-fabricated houses. (Ord. No. 12, § 1, 9-10-1973) Sec. 8-2. - State minimum standard codes. Unless otherwise provided for by subsequent ordinance or another provision of this Code, the city hereby adopts and incorporates by reference, as if set out at length herein, the latest editions of the state minimum standard codes enumerated in O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20(9)(B), as adopted and amended by the department of community affairs. (1) International Building Code, 2012 Edition, with 2014 and 2015 Georgia amendments. (2) International Residential Code, 2012 Edition, with 2014 and 2015 Georgia Amendments. (3) Fire Code, 2012 Edition, with 2014 Georgia Amendments. (4) International Plumbing Code, 2012 Edition, with 2014 and 2015 Georgia Amendments. (5) International Mechanical Code, 2012 Edition, with 2014 and 2015 Georgia Amendments. (6) International Fuel Gas Code, 2012 Edition, with 2014 and 2015 Georgia Amendments. (7) National Electrical Code, 2011 Edition. (8) International Energy Conservation Code, 2009 Edition, with Georgia Supplements and Amendments 2011 and 2012. (Ord. No. 12, § 2, 9-10-1973) Sec. 8-3. - Withholding of permit or water service for noncompliance. City officials shall not issue a building permit nor furnish water service for any dwelling house failing to qualify in accordance with section 8-2. (Ord. No. 12, § 3, 9-10-1973) Sec. 8-4. - Conflicts. (a) If any of the publications listed in section 8-2 are adopted as a state minimum code pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20 et seq., then the edition adopted by the state shall control. If any of the publications listed in section 8-2 are less stringent than the state minimum codes promulgated pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 8-2-20 et seq., the state minimum code shall control. (b) A copy of each of the publications listed in section 8-2, as adopted by the state, is filed in the city clerk's office and available for review by the public. The same is adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and from the date on which this section shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the corporate limits of the city. Sec. 8-5. - References to officials in adopted technical codes. Where reference is made to the duties of certain officials named within the technical codes which are adopted by reference in this chapter, then that official of the city as designated by the mayor who has duties corresponding to those of the named official in said technical code shall be deemed to be the responsible official insofar as enforcing the provisions of that technical code are concerned. Sec. 8-6. - Tests. Required tests are to be made at the expense of the owner, or his agent, by an approved testing laboratory or other approved agency.

div.head: Chapter 10 - BUSINESS AND BUSINESS REGULATION
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 10-1. - Suspension or revocation of license. (a) The mayor and council are hereby authorized, by written notice to the licensee, to order the suspension or revocation of any of the said licenses provided for by this article without the return to the licensee the unearned or unused portion of the fee collected. Licenses issued under this chapter may be suspended or revoked for any of the following reasons: (1) Fraud or misrepresentation in the application for the license; (2) Failure to pay all fees, taxes, or other charges imposed under the provisions of this chapter; (3) Conducting business contrary to the conditions of the license; (4) Conducting business in such a manner as to create a public nuisance or constitute a danger to public health, safety, or welfare. (b) However, upon receipt of the notice of suspension or revocation, the licensee may by written request filed with the city clerk within ten days from the date of the receipt of said notice, obtain a hearing before the mayor and council. The decision of the mayor and council after a hearing shall be final. (Ord. No. 6, § 5, 10-12-1971) Sec. 10-2. - Authorization. The city clerk is hereby authorized to issue the licenses and collect the fees or charges provided for by this article. (Ord. No. 6, § 6, 10-12-1971; Ord. No. 12-13-1982, § 7, 12-13-1982) Secs. 10-3—10-22. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - LICENSING
Sec. 10-23. - Patronage of games or devices. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, partnership or corporation to conduct for public patronage, or solicit patronage by the public, within the limits of the city, any games or devices without first obtaining a license from this city and paying the annual fee or charge to be established by the city council, from time to time. (Ord. No. 12-13-1982, § 1, 12-13-1982; Ord. of 8-11-2008) Sec. 10-24. - License term. Each of said licenses provided for herein shall be for a term of one year beginning January 1. (Ord. No. 12-13-1982, § 2, 12-13-1982) Sec. 10-25. - License holder. The holder or licensee of each license provided for by this article shall not conduct or operate the business enterprise, or mechanical or electronic device in violation of any law of the United States or the state or in violation of any ordinance of this city. (Ord. No. 12-13-1982, § 3, 12-13-1982) Sec. 10-26. - Exceptions. This article shall not be construed to authorize the city to license any of the following activities: (1) Palm readers or fortune tellers, or any individual by any means whatsoever purporting to be able to foretell the future; (2) Junkyards; (3) Any lot, which shall become the site for collecting, gathering or storing abandoned, discarded, wrecked, scrapped, ruined or junked motor vehicles, or parts thereof, when said site is less than 100 yards distant, by the most direct measurement, from any dwelling house within this city; (4) Abattoir or slaughter house; (5) Gambling. (Ord. No. 12-13-1982, § 4, 12-13-1982) Sec. 10-27. - Authority of mayor and city council. The mayor and council of this city are hereby authorized to investigate each applicant for each of the licenses covered in this article, and after said investigation, to refuse to issue to said applicant any of the licenses provided for by this article. (Ord. No. 12-13-1982, § 5, 12-13-1982) Sec. 10-28. - Suspension/revocation of licenses. (a) The mayor and council are hereby authorized in their discretion, after prior written notice to the holder of any license provided for in this article, to order the suspension or revocation of any of the said licenses provided for by this article without the return to the licensee the unused or unearned portion of the fee collected. However, upon receipt of the notice of suspension or revocation, the said licensee may, by written request filed with the city clerk within ten days from the date of the receipt of said notice, obtain a hearing before the mayor and council. The decision of the mayor and council after hearing shall be final. (b) Penalty fee of 50 percent of the annual fee to any business that has not paid by January 1, and to allow the closing of the business if fees are not paid by February 1 of the year due. (Ord. No. 12-13-1982, § 6, 12-13-1982; Ord. of 11-12-1990, § 6; Ord. of 8-11-2008) Secs. 10-29—10-59. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - ADULT BUSINESSES[1]
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Establishment, maintenance, or use of building, structure, or place for unlawful sexual purposes, O.C.G.A. § 41-3-1; prohibited conduct, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-41; governing authority has power to enact legislation to restrict operation of adult bookstores, explicit media outlets, and adult movie houses to areas zoned for commercial or industrial purposes, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-3.
Sec. 10-60. - Public purpose. Sexually oriented businesses require special supervision in order to protect and preserve the health, safety and welfare of the patrons of such businesses as well as the citizens of the community, and many types of criminal activities are frequently engendered by adult entertainment businesses, such as disorderly conduct, prostitution, solicitation, and drug trafficking and use, and adult entertainment businesses can lead to community blight, depression of property values, increased expenditure for law enforcement personnel and an increased burden on the judicial system. (Ord. No. 1996-05-13, § 1, 5-13-1996) Sec. 10-61. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Adult dancing establishment/erotic dance establishment means a business that features dancers displaying or exposing specified anatomical areas, or which features live performances by topless and/or bottomless dancers, strippers or similar entertainers, where such performances are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. The terms "adult dance establishment," "erotic dance establishment," and "adult entertainment establishment" are used interchangeably. Adult entertainment means entertainment that is characterized by an emphasis on the depiction, display or the featuring of "specified anatomical areas." Adult entertainment includes performances by persons that are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on "specified sexual activities" as defined herein, and/or performances that feature, depict, display, or emphasize their genitals, pubic region, anus, or female breasts, even if their specified anatomical areas are opaquely covered as provided herein. Alcoholic beverage shall have its usual meaning, and shall include, but not be limited to, beer, wine, liquor, wine coolers or any other beverage where the alcohol has been synthesized to make it consumable. Employee or adult entertainment establishment employee means any person who performs any service on the premises of an adult entertainment establishment on a full-time, part-time, or contract basis, whether or not the person is an employee, an independent contractor, or any other kind of agent, and whether or not said person performs such services only for tips or is paid a salary, wage, or any other type of compensation by the adult entertainment establishment. The term "employee" or "adult entertainment establishment employee" shall include, but is not limited to, entertainers, wait staff, parking attendants, security personnel, cooks and dishwashers. The term "employee" or "adult entertainment establishment employee" shall not include a person who is temporarily on the premises for the sole purpose of repair or maintenance of the premises, or any building or equipment on the premises, or for the delivery of any goods or merchandise to the premises. Good moral character means a person who has not been convicted within the past five years of a felony or any other crime involving moral turpitude. Conviction shall include pleas of nolo contendere or bond forfeitures when charged with a felony or a crime involving moral turpitude. Any person sentenced under the First Offender Act is included for the length of his sentence, not to exceed five years. In considering whether a person is of good moral character, other factors may be considered. If the licensee is a corporation, any stockholder holding five percent of the stock is subject to this section. License means a business license issued by the city to a licensee that authorizes the licensee to operate, engage in, or carry on a business. Licensee means the holder of a business license issued. Minor means any person who has not attained the age of 18 years. Operator means the manager or other person principally in charge of an adult entertainment establishment. Owner means any individual or entity holding more than a 20 percent interest in an adult entertainment establishment. Premises or licensed premises means the property or premises where an adult entertainment establishment licensed under this chapter operates, conducts, or carries on its business, and shall include the entire tract or parcel of land where such business is conducted. Specified anatomical areas includes any of the following: (1) Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals or pubic region; buttock; or female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola. (2) Human male genitalia in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. Specified sexual activity means and includes any of the following: (1) Actual or stimulated sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual act prohibited by law, or the simulation of any of the above; (2) The touching, caressing or fondling of the breasts, buttocks, anus, vulva or genitals; (3) Use of human or animal ejaculation, sodomy, oral copulation, coitus, or masturbation; (4) Masochism, erotic or sexually-oriented torture, beating, or the infliction of pain; or (5) Erotic or lewd touching, fondling, or other sexual contact with an animal by a human being. (Ord. No. 1996-05-13, § 2, 5-13-1996) Sec. 10-62. - Erotic dance establishment regulations. (a) No person, firm, partnership, corporation or other entity shall advertise or cause to be advertised an erotic dance establishment without a valid license issued pursuant to this chapter. (b) No later than March 1 of each year, an erotic dance establishment licensee shall file a verified report with the license officer showing the licensee's gross receipts and amounts paid to dancers for the preceding year. (c) No person under the age of 18 years shall be admitted to an adult entertainment establishment. (d) No licensee shall operate between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m., Monday through Friday. No licensee shall operate between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m. on Saturday. No licensee shall operate on Sunday. (e) No erotic dance establishment licensee shall serve, sell, distribute or suffer the consumption or possession of any intoxicating beverage or controlled substance (this includes brown bagging) upon his premises. (f) All licenses shall be conspicuously displayed. (g) All dancing shall occur on a platform intended for that purpose which is raised at least two feet from the level of the floor. (h) No dancing shall occur closer than ten feet to any patron. (i) No dancer shall fondle or caress any patron, and no patron shall fondle or caress any dancer. (j) All areas of an establishment licensed hereunder shall be fully lighted at all times when patrons are present. Full lighting shall mean illumination equal to 3½ footcandles per foot. (Ord. No. 1996-05-13, § 3, 5-13-1996) Sec. 10-63. - Location. No adult dance establishment or use restricted hereunder shall be located: (1) Within 1,000 feet of any parcel of land which is either named or used for residential uses or purposes; (2) Within 1,000 feet of any parcel of land upon which a church, school, governmental building, library, civic center, public park or playground is located; (3) Within 1,000 feet of any parcel of land upon which another establishment regulated hereunder is located; (4) Within 1,000 feet of any parcel of land upon which any other establishment selling alcohol is located; (5) On less than one acre of land containing at least 100 feet of road frontage. (Ord. No. 1996-05-13, § 4, 5-13-1996) Sec. 10-64. - Adult dance establishment employees. (a) Qualifications. Employees of an adult dance entertainment establishment must be at least 18 years of age. Every employee must be of good moral character, as defined in this chapter. Any employee convicted of a felony or a crime not a felony involving moral turpitude while employed shall not be able to work at an adult dance establishment for a period of five years from the date of conviction. See the definition of "employee" or "adult entertainment establishment employee" in section 10-61. (b) Approval for employment. Before any person may work on a licensed premises, such person shall file a notice with the licensing officer on forms supplied by the licensing officer. Any falsification of the form will lead to automatic disqualification or termination. An investigation fee to be established by the city council, from time to time that is nonrefundable, shall accompany the notice of intended employment. If approval is denied, the prospective employee may, within ten days of the denial request a hearing, in writing, before the mayor and council. At all times, the person is entitled to written findings of fact and to be represented by an attorney. (c) Suspension or revocation. Violation of the terms of this article shall subject an employee to suspension or revocation of a license. Said employee would have the right to appeal as set out above. (d) Independent contractors. For the purpose of this article, independent contractors shall be considered as employees and subject to the above requirement. (Ord. No. 1996-05-13, § 5, 5-13-1996) Sec. 10-65. - Application for license, cost of license, and investigation. (a) Any person, associate, partnership or corporation desiring to obtain a license to operate, engage in, conduct or carry on any adult dance establishment shall make an application to the licensing officer. (b) The cost of the license itself shall be determined by the city council, from time to time. (c) All applicants must fill out the investigation form and submit to a background check. An additional nonrefundable investigative fee as established by city council from time to time is to be paid with the license application. (d) The city shall have 30 days to complete its investigation into the background of the applicant. The mayor and council may grant permits if it finds that the applicant (including stockholders, if appropriate) meets the requirements as set forth in this article. Other criteria to be considered are whether the building meets all health and safety standards and requirements; whether the applicant has had previous permits revoked by this city or any other city; and whether the applicant is at least 21 years of age. (e) A copy of the application and investigation form are available at city hall. (Ord. No. 1996-05-13, § 6, 5-13-1996) Sec. 10-66. - License refusal; appeal. If the city determines the applicant does not meet the requirements of this article, within 30 days, it shall notify the applicant, in writing, as to the specific reasons for the denial. Any applicant may, within ten days, appeal to the mayor and council. The applicant is entitled to written findings of fact and to be represented by an attorney. (Ord. No. 1996-05-13, § 7, 5-13-1996) Sec. 10-67. - License fee and renewal. The license fee is to be established by the city council, from time to time. It is renewable annually, not later than January 1 of each year. Such license will only be renewed in the event a current licensee is in full and complete compliance with all the provisions of this article and the laws of the state. (Ord. No. 1996-05-13, § 8, 5-13-1996) Sec. 10-68. - Nontransferable. (a) No adult entertainment establishment license may be sold, transferred or assigned to any person or entity. Any such sale, transfer or assignment shall be deemed to constitute a voluntary surrender of such license, and such license shall be null and void. (b) Note: this does not affect transfers brought on by a death, and in such case, the beneficiary shall sit in place of the previous licensee. If the licensee is a corporation and the corporation is sold, transferred or assigned, or any stock authorized but not issued at the time of the granting of the license is thereafter issued or sold, the license shall be terminated. (Ord. No. 1996-05-13, § 9, 5-13-1996) Sec. 10-69. - Change of location or name. No adult entertainment establishment shall move from the location specified on its license, nor change its name, until approval has been obtained from the mayor and city council. Such approval will not be given unless all requirements and regulations contained in this Code have been met. (Ord. No. 1996-05-13, § 10, 5-13-1996) Sec. 10-70. - Appeal procedure. (a) The licensee shall, within ten days after notification of an adverse determination, submit a written notice of appeal to the city clerk. (b) The city clerk shall place the appeal on the agenda for a regular or special meeting of the mayor and council not less than five nor more than 30 days after receipt of the notice. (c) The notice shall specify the subject matter of the appeal, the date of the request or application and the date of the adverse decision. (d) The city clerk shall provide notice to the applicant, in writing, of the date for the appeal to be heard. (Ord. No. 1996-05-13, § 11, 5-13-1996) Sec. 10-71. - Hearing procedure. The mayor and council shall receive all relevant testimony and evidence from the applicant, from interested parties, and from city staff. Traditional rules of evidence shall not apply at this hearing. (Ord. No. 1996-05-13, § 12, 5-13-1996) Sec. 10-72. - Penalties. Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine according to the penalties described in the general provisions chapter of this Code. Violations shall also be grounds for suspension or termination of license issued hereunder. (Ord. No. 1996-05-13, § 13, 5-13-1996) Secs. 10-73—10-102. - Reserved.

div.head: Chapter 12 - ELECTIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Georgia Election Code, O.C.G.A. § 21-2-1 et seq.; officers generally, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-4; powers enumerated, O.C.G.A. § 36-24-2.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 12-1—12-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL
Sec. 12-19. - Municipal superintendent; duties. The city clerk is hereby appointed as the municipal superintendent. The municipal superintendent shall exercise all the powers granted under state law, including, but not limited to, the appointment and compensation of the absentee ballot clerk, poll officers, and other employees required to conduct an election; printing ballots and other election supplies required, furnishing all of the supplies, blank forms, including badges, tally sheets, and return sheets; and exercising supervisory control of registrars, poll officers, and other employees, in the performance of their duties; and performing all other duties prescribed by law in relation to the election. Sec. 12-20. - Polling place. The city hall or county commission office are designated as the polling places, as deemed appropriate. Sec. 12-21. - Chief registrar. The city clerk is hereby designated as the chief registrar with the authority to appoint such deputy registrars as are required. Sec. 12-22. - Voter criteria. No person shall vote unless he shall be: (1) Registered as an elector in the manner prescribed by law; (2) A citizen of this state and of the United States; (3) At least 18 years of age; (4) Domiciled in this city; and (5) Possessed of all other qualifications prescribed by state law. Sec. 12-23. - Polls. Polls are to be open from 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. on election day.

div.head: Chapter 14 - EMERGENCY SERVICES
div.p: (RESERVED)

div.head: Chapter 16 - ENVIRONMENT
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 16-1—16-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - HAZARD MITIGATION PLAN
Sec. 16-19. - Harris County hazard mitigation plan adopted by reference. The Harris County hazard mitigation plan is adopted as if fully set forth herein and as it may be amended from time to time. Secs. 16-20—16-41. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - LITTER[1]
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Litter, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-42 et seq.
Sec. 16-42. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Litter means any discarded or abandoned refuse, rubbish, junk, or other waste material; or dead animals that are not subject to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 4-5-4. Public or private property means the right-of-way of any road or highway; any body of water or watercourse or stream, or the shores or beaches thereof; any park, playground, building, refuge or conservation or recreation area, and residential or farm properties, timberlands or forest; or any commercial property or industrial property. (Ord. No. 5-12-75, § I, 5-12-1975) Sec. 16-43. - Unlawful activities. It shall be unlawful for any person to dump, deposit, place, throw or leave, or to cause or permit the dumping, depositing, placing, throwing or leaving of litter on any public or private property in this city, or any waters in this city, unless: (1) Such property is designated by the city or by any of its agencies for the disposal of such litter, and such person is authorized by the proper public authority to use such property. (2) Such litter is placed into a litter receptacle or container installed on such property. (3) Such person is the owner or tenant in lawful possession of such property, or has first obtained consent of the owner or tenant in lawful possession, or unless the act is done under the personal direction of said owner or tenant, all in a manner consistent with the public welfare. (Ord. No. 5-12-75, § II, 5-12-1975) Sec. 16-44. - Penalties. (a) Any person violating the provisions of section 16-43 is guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine according to the penalties described in the general provisions chapter of this Code, or, in lieu thereof, in the sound discretion of any court in which conviction is obtained, any such person may be directed by the judge of such court to pick up and remove from any public street or highway or public or private right-of-way, or public park, or, with prior permission of the legal owner or tenant in lawful possession of such property, any private property upon which it has been established by competent evidence that he has deposited litter, any and all litter deposited thereon by anyone prior to the date of execution of sentence. (b) The court may publish the names of persons convicted of violating the provisions of section 16-43. (Ord. No. 5-12-75, § III, 5-12-1975) Sec. 16-45. - Prima facie evidence. Whenever litter is thrown, deposited, dropped or dumped from any motor vehicle, boat, airplane or other conveyance in violation of section 16-43, it shall be prima facie evidence that the operator of said conveyance shall have violated this article. (Ord. No. 5-12-75, § IV, 5-12-1975) Sec. 16-46. - Enforcement. All law enforcement agencies, officers and officials of this city, or any enforcement agency, officer or any official of any commission of this city, are hereby authorized, empowered and directed to enforce compliance with this article. (Ord. No. 5-12-75, § V, 5-12-1975) Sec. 16-47. - Receptacles to be provided. All public authorities and agencies having supervision of properties of this city are authorized, empowered and instructed to establish and maintain receptacles for the deposit of litter at appropriate locations where such property is frequented by the public, and to post signs directing persons to such receptacles and serving notice of the provisions of this article and to otherwise publicize the availability of litter receptacles and requirements of this article. (Ord. No. 5-12-75, § VI, 5-12-1975) Secs. 16-48—16-67. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - WATER CONSERVATION[2]

Sec. 16-68. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Commercial means any type of building other than residential. Construction means the erection of a new building or the alteration of an existing building in connection with its repair or renovation or in connection with making an addition to an existing building and shall include the replacement of a malfunctioning, unserviceable, or obsolete faucet, shower head, toilet, or urinal in an existing building. Residential means any building or unit of a building intended for occupancy as a dwelling, but shall not include a hotel or motel. (Ord. No. 3-11-91, § 1, 3-11-1991) Sec. 16-69. - Water use limits. No construction may be initiated within the city for any residential building of any type which: (1) Employs a gravity tank-type, flushometer valve, or flushometer tank toilet that uses more than an average of 1.28 gallons of water per flush; (2) Employs a shower head that allows a flow of more than an average of 2.5 gallons of water per minute at 60 pounds per square inch of pressure; (3) Employs a urinal that uses more than an average of 0.5 gallons of water per flush; (4) Employs a lavatory faucet or lavatory replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than 1.5 gallons of water per minute; or (5) Employs a kitchen faucet or kitchen replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than two gallons of water per minute. (Ord. No. 3-11-91, § 2, 3-11-1991) Sec. 16-70. - Commercial buildings. There shall be no construction of any commercial building initiated within the city for any commercial building of any type which does not meet the requirements of section 16-69(1) through (5). (Ord. No. 3-11-91, § 3, 3-11-1991) Sec. 16-71. - Residential construction. The requirements of section 16-69 shall apply to all residential construction, which involves the repair or renovation of or addition to any existing building, when such repair or renovation of or addition to such existing building includes replacement of toilets or showers, or both. (Ord. No. 3-11-91, § 4, 3-11-1991) Sec. 16-72. - Exemptions. (a) New construction and the repair or renovation of an existing building shall be exempt from the requirements of sections 16-69 through 16-71 when: (1) The repair or renovation of the existing building does not include the replacement of the plumbing or sewage system servicing toilets, faucets or shower heads within such existing buildings; (2) When such plumbing or sewage system within such existing building, because of its capacity, design, or installation, would not function properly if the toilets, faucets or shower heads required by this article were installed; (3) Such system is a well or gravity flow from a spring and is owned privately by an individual for use in such individual's personal residence; or (4) Units to be installed are: a. Specifically designed for use by the handicapped; b. Specifically designed to withstand unusual abuse or installation in a penal institution; or c. Toilets for juveniles. (b) The owner, or his agent, of a building undergoing new construction or repair or renovation who is entitled to an exemption as specified in subsections (a)(2), (3) or (4) of this section shall obtain the exemption by applying to the city clerk. A fee to be determined by the city council, from time to time shall be charged for the inspection and issuance of such exemption. (Ord. No. 3-11-91, § 5, 3-11-1991) Sec. 16-73. - Enforcement; penalty. (a) This article shall be enforced by the office of the city clerk. Citations for violations may be issued by the city clerk. (b) Any persons, corporation, partnership or other entity violating this article shall be tried before the municipal court of the city. Upon conviction, a violation of this article may be punished by a fine according to the general penalties described in the general provisions chapter of this Code. (Ord. No. 3-11-91, § 6, 3-11-1991) Secs. 16-74—16-104. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - SOIL EROSION, SEDIMENTATION, AND POLLUTION CONTROL[3]
