In lieu of testing personnel being required, a certified copy of the test results shall be admissible. (b) No adverse personnel action may be taken against an employee subjected to a drug and alcohol test unless the hearing officer finds by a preponderance of the evidence that reasonable suspicion existed to request the test and that the test results are accurate. (c) Within five days following the hearing, the hearing officer shall issue a written decision and a brief finding of facts supporting the decision. (Ord. No. 1996-04-15, § XII, 4-15-1996) Sec. 30-69. - Laboratory testing requirements. All drug and alcohol testing of employees and applicants shall be conducted at medical facilities or laboratories selected by the city. At all times, the employee's right to privacy must be considered in the testing procedure. However, this right cannot interfere with or inhibit the accurate testing of the employee. All laboratories must submit a description of their sample retrieving procedure. Other requirements to be considered in selecting a facility are: (1) Methods of analysis which ensure reliable test results, including the use of gas chromatography/mass spectrometry to confirm positive test results. (2) Maintenance of the test sample and the chain of custody procedures which ensure proper identification, labeling and handling of test samples. (3) Retention and storage procedures which ensure reliable results on confirmation of tests of original samples. Storage will not be required beyond 60 days. (Ord. No. 1996-04-15, § XII, 4-15-1996)

div.head: Chapter 32 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT
div.p: Sec. 32-1. - Planning commission. Be it ordained by the mayor and city councilmembers and is hereby ordained by order of the same, that a planning commission is established for the city. (Ord. of 7-12-1959)

div.head: Chapter 34 - SOLID WASTE[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— Pursuant to the Georgia Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act as set forth in O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq., the city is included in the county's comprehensive solid waste management plan adopted October 19, 1993. State Law reference— Georgia Comprehensive Solid Waste Management Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq.; local, multijurisdictional and regional solid waste plans, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-31.1; unlawful placement of signs within right-of-way of public road, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-51; authorization to provide garbage and solid waste collection and disposal, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(2).
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 34-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Garbage means waste matter intended for food or that attends the preparation, use, cooking, dealing in or storage of meat, fish, fowl, fruit, or vegetables. Hazardous waste means pesticides and drugs (other than normal household use), pathological waste, chemical waste, inflammable or explosive materials, and similar material that the county board of health may consider a likely hazard to the public health or safety. Mayor means the mayor of the City of Hamilton or his authorized representative. Person means any individual, partnership, corporation, association, or similar entity. Scavenge means uncontrolled picking from discarded solid waste materials. Solid waste means putrescible and non-putrescible wastes, except human body waste or animal excrement, and shall include garbage rubbish (paper, cartons, boxes, wood, tree branches, yard trimmings, furniture, appliances, metals, tin cans, glass, crockery, or dunnage), ashes, street refuse, dead animals, industrial wastes (waste materials generated in industrial operations), residue from incineration, food processing wastes, demolition wastes, construction wastes, and any other waste material in a solid or semi-solid state not otherwise defined in this article. Waste means unwanted or discarded material, except human body waste or animal excrement. (Ord. No. 7, § 1, 4-12-1971; Ord. No. 11, § 1, 9-10-1973) Sec. 34-2. - Residence responsibility. Any residence within the city which may produce any solid waste shall be responsible for disposal, storage and other handling of said waste. (Ord. No. 95-1-9, § 1, 1-9-1995; Ord. No. 9-12-95, § 1, 9-12-1995) Sec. 34-3. - Commercial responsibility. Commercial, industrial, medical, or governmental facilities shall likewise be responsible for storage and disposal of all solid waste products at said facilities. (Ord. No. 95-1-9, § 2, 1-9-1995; Ord. No. 9-12-95, § 2, 9-12-1995) Sec. 34-4. - Curbside pickup. Any residential or commercial facility disposing of waste by means of county curbside pickup shall provide such containers as necessary to contain all waste left at curbside. Containers left at curbside must be of a size not to exceed size and volume limits set by the county and shall have lids to prevent spillage or loss of said waste. (Ord. No. 95-1-9, § 3, 1-9-1995; Ord. No. 9-12-95, § 3, 9-12-1995) Sec. 34-5. - Preparation and storage of waste. Leaving waste at curbside in plastic bags will be permitted, provided that all bags are tied or otherwise sealed to prevent spillage or loss of waste, and bags are not left at curbside more than six hours before scheduled pickup. (Ord. No. 95-1-9, § 4, 1-9-1995; Ord. No. 9-12-95, § 4, 9-12-1995) Sec. 34-6. - Residence/contractor-provided dumpsters. Any residence or commercial facility that may choose to contract the services of companies or contractors to provide dumpsters or other collection/storage containers shall: (1) Have only containers equipped with covers or lids that shall remain closed unless waste is being deposited or removed for disposal. (2) Not place containers in such a manner as to hinder or impose upon neighboring easements, properties or rights-of-way. (3) Have dumpsters enclosed by fencing or other partition constructed in such a manner to conceal said dumpster from public view and protect said container from invasion by stray or wild animals. (4) Ensure that spillage or overrun waste shall be gathered and returned to the dumpster (by the proprietor or facility responsible for said container) as soon as possible following a spill. (5) Ensure that dumpsters are emptied frequently to prevent overrun. (Ord. No. 95-1-9, § 5, 1-9-1995; Ord. No. 9-12-95, § 5, 9-12-1995) Sec. 34-7. - Rubbish bundles. Rubbish may be placed in containers not over 50 pounds gross weight when placed for collection or in bundles not over 50 pounds each. Limbs or cuttings shall be not over four feet in length and not over four inches in diameter. Larger items in size or weight shall be handled at special fees which may be established by the mayor upon request. (Ord. No. 7, § 5, 4-12-1971; Ord. No. 11, § 5, 9-10-1973) Sec. 34-8. - Storage. No person shall place any solid waste in any street, public place, roadway or private premises except in proper containers for collection or under the express prior approval of the mayor. No person shall place any solid waste in any stream, lake or other body of water. (Ord. No. 7, § 6, 4-12-1971; Ord. No. 11, § 6, 9-10-1973) Sec. 34-9. - Accumulations. Any unauthorized accumulation of solid waste on any premises is hereby declared to be a nuisance and is prohibited. Failure to remove any existing accumulation of solid waste within such reasonable time as may be fixed by written notice of the mayor shall be deemed a violation of this article. (Ord. No. 7, § 7, 4-12-1971; Ord. No. 11, § 7, 9-10-1973) Secs. 34-10—34-36. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - TOXIC AND HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES
Sec. 34-37. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Chemical means any substance, which, when exposed to fire or combined with another substance, produces a gas, mist or fume listed in the table. Data sheets means material safety data sheets showing the chemical composition of the substance along with the inherent hazards. These are the same sheets required by federal law that all importers, manufacturers and distributors (dealers) furnish a copy of to their customers. mg/m 3 means milligrams per cubic meter. PPM means parts per million. Table means the substances listed in OSHA 1910.1000, a copy of which tables Z-1 and Z-2 are attached to the ordinance from which this article is derived. (Ord. No. 7-14-86, 7-14-1986) Sec. 34-38. - Chemicals. It is the responsibility of the owner or possessor, or both, if different parties, to have on hand data sheets for each chemical on the premises. These data sheets and chemicals shall be available for inspection by the appropriate city officials during reasonable business hours. (Ord. of 7-14-1986) Sec. 34-39. - Storage. (a) Any chemical which produces an exposure of ten PPM and/or 25 mg/m 3 , or less, shall be stored in a fireproof enclosure. (b) Any chemical which produces an exposure of 11 PPM and/or 26 mg/m 3 to 250 PPM and/or 400 mg/m 3 should be stored in a fire-retardant container. This does not apply to vehicles. (Ord. No. 7-14-86, 7-14-1986) Sec. 34-40. - Responsibility. (a) It shall be the responsibility of the owner or possessor, or both, if different parties, to notify the city clerk of any chemicals which he receives which produce an exposure of 250 PPM and/or 400 mg/m 3 or less. This notification shall occur within three working days after receipt of such chemicals. Quantities of one gallon or less or ten pounds or less, are exempt from this reporting requirement. (b) It is the responsibility of the owner or possessor, or both, if different parties, to have on hand data sheets for each chemical on the premises. These data sheets and chemicals shall be available for inspection by the appropriate city officials during reasonable business hours. (Ord. No. 7-14-86, 7-14-1986) Sec. 34-41. - Penalties. (a) A fine according to the penalties described in the general provisions chapter of this Code shall be assessed for each day that the subject chemicals are in the possession of any person or legal entity and the same has not been reported in accordance with the requirements of this article. (b) A fine according to the penalties described in the general provisions chapter of this Code shall be assessed for each day that the subject chemicals are not stored according to the requirements of this article. (c) A fine according to the penalties described in the general provisions chapter of this Code shall be assessed for each day during which a data sheet is not produced to the proper authorities as required by this article. (d) The individuals, corporations, partnerships, and other entities in possession of the subject chemicals shall be responsible for meeting all the requirements of this article and shall be subject to the fines as set forth herein. (Ord. of 8-16-1986)

div.head: Chapter 36 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— City has power to construct and maintain roads, including curbs, sidewalks, street lights and devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4); municipal street systems generally, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-90 et seq.; obstructing sidewalks or other public passages, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-43; damaging public property, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25; obstructions in street, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-10; municipal authority to regulate streets, alleys and sidewalks, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 36-1—36-39. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - GATHERINGS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Control of mass gatherings, O.C.G.A. § 31-27-1 et seq.
Sec. 36-40. - Use of public property regulated. Be it ordained by the city council that the regulation of the conduct of groups and individuals using the public square and all other public property located within the city is necessary for the good order, welfare and proper government of the city and the residents therein. (Ord. No. 80-9-22(1), § 1, 10-13-1980) Sec. 36-41. - Activity declared a privilege. The use of said public square and other public property of said city is declared to be a privilege and said privilege should be regulated in order to be enjoyed. (Ord. No. 80-9-22(1), § 2, 10-13-1980) Sec. 36-42. - Games for hazarding money, etc. The gathering together or assembling of two or more persons upon or in said public square or upon or in the other public property of the city for the purpose of engaging in any game of chance or for the hazarding of money or other thing of value is unlawful assembly on a public place to gamble, and is hereby declared to be an offense against the good order, welfare and proper government of said city. (Ord. No. 80-9-22(1), § 3, 10-13-1980) Sec. 36-43. - Penalties. Any violation of the provisions of this article shall be punished according to the penalties described in the general provisions chapter of this Code. (Ord. No. 80-9-22(1), § 4, 10-13-1980) Secs. 36-44—36-74. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - PARADES[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Operation of motorcycles and motor vehicles in parades, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-7.
Sec. 36-75. - Authorization. The governing authority of this city is hereby authorized to issue permits, upon proper application, to persons, firms, corporations or associations to conduct a parade or marching demonstration within the limits of this city. (Ord. No. 3, § 1, 2-9-1970) Sec. 36-76. - Application for permit. Prior to the granting of a permit for a parade or marching demonstration within the city limits of this city, an application must be filed at the department of motor vehicles by the person desiring the permit. (1) The application must set forth the route of the march or demonstration, the hour, date and point of origin of the parade or marching demonstration, the probable duration or period of time required for the parade or marching demonstration from its point of origin to the point of disbanding, and the point of disbanding or dispersing; (2) The application must show the full name and address of the applicant or applicants, and the full name and address of the organization sponsoring the parade or marching demonstration, if different from the applicant; (3) The application must also show whether the applicant and the sponsor are either individual, partnership, corporation or association and such additional information as the governing authority may require. (Ord. No. 3, § 2, 2-9-1970) Sec. 36-77. - Permit timing. The permit authorized by this article must be obtained not less than 72 hours prior to the hour of the starting of the parade or marching demonstration. (Ord. No. 3, § 3, 2-9-1970) Sec. 36-78. - Parade regulations—Formation of marching participants. The individuals participating in the authorized parade or marching demonstration shall march so that at no time will there be more than four individual participants abreast. All persons following shall remain in file behind the leading participants and not nearer than three feet to the participant ahead of him. (Ord. No. 3, § 4, 2-9-1970) Sec. 36-79. - Same—Formation and dimensions of participating vehicles. Vehicles, including floats, shall not exceed the legal width permitted by the state highway department, and during the parade or demonstration shall remain in the line of the march. (Ord. No. 3, § 5, 2-9-1970) Sec. 36-80. - Same—Restrictions on signage and songs. No signs shall be displayed that are rude, vulgar or obscene or offensive and no slogans, charts or songs shall be permitted that are rude, vulgar, obscene or offensive. (Ord. No. 3, § 6, 2-9-1970) Sec. 36-81. - Permit not license to trespass or violate city, state or federal laws. Any permit granted in accordance with this article by the governing authority does not include permission for the participants of the parade or marching demonstration to trespass on private or public property nor to violate any ordinance of this city, nor to violate any law of the state or of the United States. (Ord. No. 3, § 7, 2-9-1970)

div.head: Chapter 38 - TAXATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Taxation power of municipal and county governments, Ga. Const. art. IX, § IX, ¶ I(a) and (b)(2); revenue and taxation, O.C.G.A. title 48; ad valorem taxation of property, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-1 et seq.; municipal taxation, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-350 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 38-1—38-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS BUSINESS LICENSE TAX
Sec. 38-19. - Rate. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93 there is hereby levied an annual business license tax upon state and national banking associations, federal savings and loan associations, and state building and loan associations at the rate of 0.25 percent of the gross receipts of said institutions as defined. Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, the minimum amount of business license tax due from any depository financial institutions pursuant to this article shall be $1,000.00 per year. (Ord. of 5-2-1907; Ord. No. 12-28-83, § 1, 12-28-1983) Sec. 38-20. - Gross receipts. For purposes of this article, the term "gross receipts" shall mean the total amount of revenue generated from the sources itemized in this section during the calendar year immediately preceding the date on which the tax imposed by the ordinance is due: (1) Items to be included in the calculation of gross receipts with respect to banks are as follows: a. Interest and fees on loans, less any interest collected on those portions of loans sold and serviced for others; b. Interest on balances with other depository financial institutions; c. Interest on federal or correspondent funds sold and securities purchased under agreements of resale; d. Interest on other bonds, notes, and debentures, excluding interest on obligations in the state or its political subdivisions and obligations on the United States; e. Dividends on stocks; f. Income from direct lease financing; g. Income from fiduciary activities; h. Service charges on deposit accounts; i. Other service charges, commissions, and fees; and j. Other income. (2) Items to be included in the calculation of gross receipts with respect to savings and loan associations are as follows: a. Interest on mortgage loans less any interest collected on those portions of loans sold in service for others; b. Interest on mortgages, participations, or mortgage-backed securities; c. Interest on real estate sold on contract; d. Discounts on mortgage loans purchased; e. Interest on other loans, excluding interest on obligations of the state or its political subdivisions and obligations of the United States; f. Interest and dividends on investments and deposits; g. Loan fees; h. Loan servicing fees; i. Other fees and charges; j. Gross income from real estate owned operations; k. Net income from office building operations; l. Gross income from real estate held for investment; m. Net income from service corporations and subsidiaries; n. Miscellaneous operating income; o. Profit on sale of real estate owned, investment securities, loans, and other assets; and p. Miscellaneous non-operating income. (3) The following items shall be deducted from gross receipts calculated pursuant to subsections (1) or (2) of this section: a. An amount equal to the amount of interest paid on all liabilities for the period; b. An amount equal to income derived from the authorized activities of any domestic international banking facility operating pursuant to article 5(a) of chapter 1 of title 7 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated; c. An amount equal to any income arising from the conduct of a banking business with persons or entities located outside of the United States, its territories or possessions; d. An amount equal to a depository financial institution's gross income which is taxed under the tax laws of a state other than Georgia; and e. To the extent that any deductions are made pursuant to subsections (3)b through d of this section, any deductions taken under subsection (3)a of this section shall be reduced by the same proportion that the deductions in subsections (3)b through d of this section bear to the gross receipts of the depository financial institution as calculated before making any deductions pursuant to subsections (3)a through d of this section. (Ord. No. 12-28-83, § 2, 12-28-1983) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 48-6-95. Sec. 38-21. - Due date; filing of return. (a) Each depository financial institution within the city shall file a return of its gross receipts with the city on March 1 of the year following the year in which such gross receipts were measured. Said returns shall be in the manner and in the form prescribed by the commissioner of the department of banking, and shall be based upon the allocation method set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93(d). The tax levied pursuant to this article shall be assessed and collected based upon the information provided in said return. (b) The due date of taxes levied by this article shall be December 20 of each year. (Ord. No. 12-28-83, § 3, 12-28-1983) Secs. 38-22—38-45. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - HOTEL/MOTEL OCCUPANCY EXCISE TAX[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Tourist courts, O.C.G.A. § 31-28-1 et seq.; operators of hotels, inns and roadhouses, O.C.G.A. § 43-21-1 et seq.; local excise taxes on rooms, lodgings and accommodations, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-50 et seq.
Sec. 38-46. - Intent. The intent of this article is to impose an excise tax on hotel/motel occupancy in the city pursuant to the provisions of article 3, chapter 13, title 48 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, and to provide that the funds therefrom are used for the purpose of promoting, attracting, stimulating and developing conventions and tourism in the city, and for the provision of other local government services. (Ord. No. 11-20-89, § 1, 11-20-1989) Sec. 38-47. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Due date means the 20th day after the close of the monthly period or the quarterly period for which the tax is to be computed. Operators required to file monthly returns and operators required to file quarterly returns under the state retailers' and consumers' sales and use tax approved February 1951, as now or hereafter amended, shall have the same due dates under this article. Guest room means a room occupied, or intended, arranged, or designed for occupancy, by one or more occupants for the purpose of living quarters or residential use. This term shall not include meeting rooms or exhibition halls. Hotel/motel means any structure or any portion of a structure including any lodginghouse, roominghouse, dormitory, Turkish bath, bachelor hotel, studio hotel, motel, motor hotel, auto court, inn, apartment or condominium, public club or private club, containing guest rooms and which is occupied or is intended or designed for occupancy by guests, whether rent is paid in money, goods, labor or otherwise. It does not include any jail, hospital, asylum, sanitarium, orphanage, prison, detention or other buildings in which human beings are housed and detained under legal restraint. Monthly period means the calendar months of any year. Occupancy means the use or possession, or the right to the use or possession of any room or apartment in a hotel/motel or the right to the use or possession of the furnishings or to the services and accommodations accompanying the use and possession of the room or apartment. Operator means any person operating a hotel/motel in the city and subject to a city business license, including, but not limited to, the owner or proprietor of such premises, lessee, sub-lessee, lender in possession, licensee or any other person operating such hotel/motel. Permanent resident means any occupant as of a given date who has or shall have occupied or has or shall have the right of occupancy of any guest room in a hotel/motel for at least ten consecutive days next preceding such date. Person means an individual, firm, partnership, joint venture association, social club, fraternal organization, joint stock company, corporation, nonprofit corporation or cooperative nonprofit membership, estate, trust, business trust, receiver, trustee, syndicate or any other group or combination acting as a unit, the plural as well as the singular number, excepting the United States of America, the state and any political subdivision of either upon which the city is without power to impose the tax herein provided. Quarter means a three-calendar-month period of time as specified in the Georgia Retailers' and Consumers' Sales and Use Tax Act, as the same now or hereafter exists or is amended. Rent means the consideration received for occupancy valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits, and property or services of any kind or nature, and also the amount for which credit is allowed by the operator to the occupant, without any deduction except for food, which is separately stated and billed. Return means any return filed or required to be filed as herein provided. Tax means the tax imposed by this chapter. (Ord. No. 11-20-89, § 2, 11-20-1989) Sec. 38-48. - Imposition and rate of tax. (a) Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(1), there is hereby imposed and there shall be paid a tax of three percent of the rent of every occupancy of a guest room in a hotel/motel in the city. (b) 100 percent of the net funds collected under this hotel/motel tax shall be spent or used for the promotion of tourism and conventions by the city. (Ord. No. 11-20-89, § 3, 11-20-1989) Sec. 38-49. - Collection of tax by operator; receipting; reporting and remittance of taxes collected. (a) Every operator maintaining a place of business in the city, subject to a city business license, and renting guest rooms in the city and which is not exempt under section 38-50, shall collect a tax of one percent on the amount of rent from the occupant. (b) Such operator shall provide a receipt to each occupant to whom said tax is charged, showing the amount of rent and the amount of all taxes thereon by category. (c) All taxes due shall be collected at the time rent is collected. (Ord. No. 11-20-89, § 4, 11-20-1989) Sec. 38-50. - Exemptions. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(a)(1), no tax shall be imposed hereunder upon a permanent resident or upon state or local government officials or employees when traveling on official business. (Ord. No. 11-20-89, § 5, 11-20-1989) Sec. 38-51. - Determination of taxes, returns, and payments. (a) Due date of taxes. All amounts of such taxes shall be due and payable monthly or quarterly as the case may be, on or before the 20th day of each month or quarter next succeeding such monthly or quarterly payment period as set forth in section 38-47. (b) Return; time of filing; persons required to file; contents. On or before the 20th day of the month/quarter following each monthly/quarterly period, each operator shall file a return with the clerk showing the gross rent, rent from permanent residents, rent from government officials or employees while traveling on official business, taxable rent and the amount of taxes due for the return period. (c) Collection fee allowed operators. Operators collecting the tax shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting and payment of the amount due, if such amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of deduction shall be the same rate authorized under O.C.G.A. § 48-13-94, as now or hereafter amended. (Ord. No. 11-20-89, § 7, 11-20-1989) Sec. 38-52. - Deficiency determinations. (a) Re-computation of tax; authority; basis of re-computation. If the city clerk is not satisfied with the return or returns of the tax or the amount of tax required to be paid to the city by any operator, the clerk may compute and determine the amount of tax on the basis of the operator's sales and the tax returns filed with the state. Such records shall be the only record required to be kept or furnished under this article. One or more deficiency determinations may be made of the amount due for one or more monthly or quarterly periods. (b) Notice of determination; service. The clerk or his designated representative shall give to the operator written notice of any such determination of tax due. The notice may be served personally or by mail, and if by mail, such service shall be addressed to the operator at his business address as it appears in the records of the clerk. Service by mail shall be effective when delivered by certified mail with a receipt signed by the addressee. (c) Time within which notice of deficiency determination is to be mailed. Except in the case of failure to make a return, every notice of deficiency determination shall be mailed within three years after the 20th day of the calendar month following the monthly or quarterly period for which the amount is proposed to be determined, or within three years after the return is filed, whichever period shall last expire. (Ord. No. 11-20-89, § 8, 11-20-1989) Sec. 38-53. - Determination if no return made. Estimate of gross receipts. If any operator shall fail to make a return, the clerk shall make an estimate of the amount of gross receipts of such operator, or as the case may be, of the amount of the total rentals in the city which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the period or periods in respect to which the person failed to make a return and shall be based upon the operator's sales and use tax returns filed with the state. Written notice shall be given in the manner prescribed in section 38-52(b). (Ord. No. 11-20-89, § 9, 11-20-1989) Sec. 38-54. - Administration of article. (a) Authority of city clerk. The city clerk shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the collection of the tax imposed hereby. (b) Records required from operator; form. The only records required of an operator's renting guest rooms in the city to a person shall be the operator's sale and use tax reports filed with the state. An operator, in submitting sales and use tax reports, shall have the right to separately state and deduct from the sales and use tax reports any meals furnished as a part of the service covered hereby. (Ord. No. 11-20-89, § 10, 11-20-1989) Secs. 38-55—38-81. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - INSURANCE PREMIUMS TAX
Sec. 38-82. - Due date for license fees. License fees imposed in sections 38-83 and 38-84 shall be due and payable on the first day of each year. (Ord. No. 9-12-1983, § 5, 9-12-1983; Ord. No. 93-12-13, § 5, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 2011-08-08, § 5, 8-8-2011) Sec. 38-83. - Insurers' license fees. There is hereby levied for each year an annual license fee upon each insurer doing business within the city in the amount to be determined by city council, from time to time. For each separate business location in excess of one not covered by section 38-84, which is operating on behalf of such insurers within the city, there is hereby levied a license fee in the amount to be determined by city council, from time to time. For the purposes of this article, the term "insurer" means a company which is authorized to transact business in any of the classes of insurance designated in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5. (Ord. No. 9-12-1983, § 1, 9-12-1983; Ord. No. 8-13-84, § 1, 8-13-1984; Ord. No. 93-12-13, § 1, 12-13-1993; Ord. of 1-5-2009; Ord. No. 2011-08-08, § 1, 8-8-2011) State Law reference— Powers of municipal corporations to impose license fees on life insurance companies, O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8. Sec. 38-84. - License fees for insurers insuring certain risks at additional business locations. For each separate business location not otherwise subject to a license fee hereunder, operated and maintained by a business organization which is engaged in the business of lending money or transacting sales involving term financing, and in connection with such loans or sales offers, solicits or takes application for insurance through a licensed agent of an insurer for insurance, said insurer shall pay an additional license fee to be determined by the city council from time to time per location for the year 2012 and for each year thereafter. (Ord. No. 9-12-1983, § 2, 9-12-1983; Ord. No. 8-13-84, § 3, 8-13-1984; Ord. No. 93-12-13, § 2, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 2011-08-08, § 2, 8-8-2011) Sec. 38-85. - Gross premiums tax imposed on life insurers. There is hereby levied for the year 2012 and for each year thereafter an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer writing life, accident and sickness insurance within the state in an amount equal to one percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1. The term "gross direct premiums," as used in this section, shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by section 38-83. (Ord. No. 9-12-1983, § 3, 9-12-1983; Ord. No. 8-13-84, § 3, 8-13-1984; Ord. No. 93-12-13, § 3, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 2011-08-08, § 3, 8-8-2011) Sec. 38-86. - Gross premiums tax; all other insurers. There is hereby levied for each year an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer, other than an insurer transacting business in the class of insurance designated in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5(1), doing business within the state in an amount equal to 2½ percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2. The term "gross direct premiums," as used in this section, shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by section 38-83. (Ord. No. 9-12-1983, § 4, 9-12-1983; Ord. No. 93-12-13, § 4, 12-13-1993; Ord. No. 2011-08-08, § 4, 8-8-2011) Secs. 38-87—38-115. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - PURCHASING POLICY[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Powers of municipal governing authorities, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-92.
Sec. 38-116. - Purchasing official. The city will appoint a purchasing official to handle the aspects of the purchase order policy. This appointment will remain in effect until the city appoints a new purchasing official. This person will be responsible for obtaining bids, providing purchase order numbers, managing the budget area of purchasing, and maintaining a proper inventory of purchased items. The purchasing official will handle both everyday purchases and any and all grant purchases. The purchase system will utilize the decentralized method. (Ord. of 3-9-2009, § 1; Ord. No. 12-14-2009, § 1, 12-14-2009) Sec. 38-117. - Purchase orders. The purchasing official will maintain the purchase order books in his office and will be responsible for the issuance of the purchase orders. All purchases must have a purchase order number obtained through the purchasing official by phone or in person. All purchase order requests must be complete. The name and address of the company, the date of order, date required, terms, shipping, department requesting purchase and the name of the requestor must be completed along with the quantity, description, and price of the order. Cost may be added later if not available at the time of order. All purchase orders must be signed by the purchasing official and by the mayor or one councilmember prior to the purchase or before any payment is made. Any purchase that costs $2,500.00 or more must have two signatures prior to the purchase or payment of the invoice. Any purchase that is $5,000.00 or more requires the approved bidding process to be implemented. (Ord. of 3-9-2009, § 2; Ord. No. 12-14-2009, § 2, 12-14-2009) Sec. 38-118. - Emergency purchases. All emergency purchases must have a verbal approval from the mayor and two councilmembers or by three councilmembers prior to purchase. An emergency purchase would be one that would be required to prevent the possibility of endangering or jeopardizing the health and welfare of the citizens or employees or the governmental function of the city in any department. (Ord. of 3-9-2009, § 3; Ord. No. 12-14-2009, § 3, 12-14-2009) Sec. 38-119. - Receipts. The purchasing official will be notified of all receipts of orders and all invoices will be delivered to his office with a notice of the condition of delivery. Upon the receipt of the invoice, the purchasing official will match the invoice and purchase order for forwarding to the city clerk for payment. (Ord. of 3-9-2009, § 4; Ord. No. 12-14-2009, § 4, 12-14-2009) Sec. 38-120. - Bids. The city requires bidding on any purchases of $5,000.00 or more. The city follows the O.C.G.A. requirements for public hearings and advertisement of bids. Purchases are strictly prohibited to be split in order to avoid the bidding requirement. Quotations may be obtained by sealed bid, written quote or by telephone quote. It is the city's policy to not disclose pricing to vendors during the bidding process. Sealed bids will be time and date stamped upon receipt and opened at the appointed public hearing time. All bids will be reviewed and accepted at the discretion of the mayor and council with the purchasing officer's recommendation. A bidder's list is maintained at city hall. (Ord. of 3-9-2009, § 5; Ord. No. 12-14-2009, § 5, 12-14-2009) Sec. 38-121. - Petty cash purchases. The city recognizes the need for low-dollar purchases that do not justify the cost and time of issuing a purchase order. These purchases will be handled out of petty cash at the city hall. All petty cash purchases will require a cash receipt and a verbal or written approval from the purchasing officer to the city hall. (Ord. of 3-9-2009, § 6; Ord. No. 12-14-2009, § 6, 12-14-2009) Sec. 38-122. - Credit cards. The city has obtained the use of credit cards for qualified employees. The cards are to be used for city purposes only. Telephone or computer orders will require a purchase order number. Credit card invoices are to be reviewed by the purchasing officer before payment is rendered. (Ord. of 3-9-2009, § 7; Ord. No. 12-14-2009, § 7, 12-14-2009) Sec. 38-123. - Payment. Payment is to be issued after the purchasing officer has completed the purchase process and purchase orders have been signed. If an item has been back-ordered, a partial payment must be issued for items received. The original purchase order number is to be used for the back-ordered items as they are received. (Ord. of 3-9-2009, § 8; Ord. No. 12-14-2009, § 8, 12-14-2009) Sec. 38-124. - Federal grant funds. The city follows the regulations of OMB circular A-102 when purchasing with federal grant funds. (Ord. of 3-9-2009, § 9; Ord. No. 12-14-2009, § 9, 12-14-2009) Sec. 38-125. - Gifts. The city's purchasing officer and employees making purchases on behalf of the city, should never accept any gifts from any vendors. (Ord. of 3-9-2009, § 10; Ord. No. 12-14-2009, § 10, 12-14-2009)

div.head: Chapter 40 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Cities are authorized to exercise power over parking facilities and traffic control devices, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4) and (11); power of local authorities with respect to uniform rules of the road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-370 et seq.; jurisdiction of municipal courts over misdemeanor traffic offenses, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-21(a).
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 40-1. - Adoption by reference. Pursuant to chapter 6 of title 40 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, Code sections 40-6-372 through 40-6-376, Code sections 40-6-1 to 40-6-376 (except for Code sections 40-6-393 through 40-6-394) of that chapter known as the Uniform Rules of the Road and the definitions contained in Code section 40-1-1 are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of this municipality with life effect as if recited herein. (Ord. No. 80-9-22, § 1, 1-8-1979) Sec. 40-2. - Penalties. Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of any provision of this chapter shall be as for a misdemeanor by a fine or by imprisonment, or both such fine and imprisonment. (Ord. No. 80-9-22, § 2, 1-8-1979) Sec. 40-3. - Private parking violation by motor vehicles. In accordance with the authority granted by O.C.G.A. § 40-6-252, the city council hereby ordains and enacts into law the City Criminal Trespass by Motor Vehicle Ordinance, and it is hereby ordained by the mayor and council to adopt by reference the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 40-6-252. (Ord. of 8-8-2016(2)) Secs. 40-4—40-24. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - SPEED ZONES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Alteration of speed limits by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-183.
Sec. 40-25. - Adoption of speed zones. The speed zones adopted by the city council shall be maintained in the office of the city clerk and shall be made available for copying or inspection by any person. Secs. 40-26—40-50. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - PARKING
Sec. 40-51. - Parking regulations. No motor vehicle of any kind shall be permitted to park at any time in the city as follows: (1) In a space designated by the city or its designee as a handicapped parking zone, unless the vehicle parked in that zone is authorized to be parked in that handicapped parking zone, by permit or by vehicle license tag. Authorized tags shall include handicapped tags, disabled veterans tags or tags for any other disabled person authorized under GA Code 40-2-74 or GA Code 40-2-74.1. (2) Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant or in a designated fire zone. (3) It shall be illegal to park a vehicle with a missing or expired tag or registration sticker. (4) No vehicle shall park in the city street for longer than 48 hours. (5) Within 15 feet of an intersection. (6) Facing the wrong direction. (7) Opposite the flow of traffic. (8) Parked in a lane used by moving traffic. (9) More than 12 inches from the curb or the edge of the roadway. (10) At an improper angle. (11) In a posted no parking zone by signs and lines. (12) Park longer than the posted time limits. (13) In a manner that obstructs a crosswalk or sidewalk. (14) In front of, in or within eight feet of a private driveway. (15) In a manner that constitutes double parking. (16) On a curb or sidewalk. (17) In a manner that blocks entrance to or exit from a garage. (18) In an area designated as prohibited parking by temporary regulation when signs are erected giving notice. (19) In a designated loading zone. (20) In a zone designated for Hamilton Public Safety Vehicles Only or for City of Hamilton Parking Only. Any vehicle in violation of any provision of this article, it shall be permissible for the police department to tow or have towed such vehicle to the impounding lot of the city's designated towing company. Decisions to tow a vehicle for violations under this article shall be made at the discretion of the police chief or his designee. (Ord. No. 2017-06-12, § 1, 6-12-2017) Sec. 40-52. - Jurors excused from parking regulations. (a) Jurors on duty in the courts of Harris County are hereby excused from parking restrictions in legal parking areas on public streets according to the following regulations: (1) A juror who leaves his summons for service visible to an inspecting officer will not be given a violation ticket by such officer on the date shown on the summons. (2) Should a parking summons be left on such jurors' vehicle, the same may be validated by the jury manager whose validation stamp shall show that the juror was on duty at the time the parking violation was issued. (b) The jury manager is authorized to return such summons to the police department or have the same returned in satisfaction of the obligation of the juror to appear. (Ord. No. 2017-06-12, § 2, 6-12-2017)

div.head: Chapter 42 - UTILITIES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Theft of utilities, O.C.G.A. title 16, ch. 7.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 42-1. - Rate schedule. The water and sewer rate schedule shall be established from time to time by the city council, and shall be available for examination in the office of the city clerk. (Ord. No. 101A, § 1, 10-10-1977; Ord. No. 1984-02-21, § 1, 2-21-1984; Ord. of 2-21-1984, § 1; Res. No. 1994-04-11, § 1, 4-11-1994; Ord. No. 2002-11-18a, 11-18-2002; Ord. No. 2002-11-18, 11-18-2002; Ord. No. 2005-01-14, 1-14-2005) Sec. 42-2. - Residential tap on fees. Residential tap on fees will be established by the city council, from time to time. (Res. No. 05-10-04) Secs. 42-3—42-22. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - WATER[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Georgia Water Quality Control Act, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-20 et seq.; municipalities authorized to acquire, construct, operate and maintain water and sewage systems, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-5; adoption of ordinances, rules and regulations relating to payment for street improvements and construction of water, gas and sewer connections; payment of costs of connections, O.C.G.A. § 36-39-7.
Sec. 42-23. - Water system. The officials of this city are hereby charged with the efficient conduct and operation of the water system owned by the city. (Ord. No. 8, § 1, 11-11-1969) Sec. 42-24. - Water statement. As promptly as possible after the 25th day of each month, each patron shall receive a statement of the sum due for water service used by said patron the preceding month. (Ord. No. 8, § 2, 11-11-1969) Sec. 42-25. - Nonpayment. All charges for water consumed by the patron during the preceding month shall become delinquent on the 15th day of the month following the receipt of the statement due for water services. (Ord. No. 8, § 3, 11-11-1969) Sec. 42-26. - Disconnection. The water services shall be disconnected when and if the patron fails to pay the sum in full within 40 days of the due date. (Ord. No. 8, § 4, 11-11-1969) Sec. 42-27. - Restoration of service. The water service shall be resumed or cut on as soon as all sums due for water service have been paid in full plus a charge for connecting or turning on or re-establishing the water service to such patron. (Ord. No. 8, § 5, 11-11-1969) Sec. 42-28. - Application for water service. The consumer (homeowner living on premises) shall make a cash security deposit for residential and for commercial water service and an additional amount for sewer service, and the consumer living in residential rental housing shall make a cash security deposit for water and for sewer service, in amounts to be determined by the city council from time to time. (Ord. No. 101A, § 2, 10-10-1977; Ord. No. 1984-02-21, § 2, 2-21-1984; Ord. of 2-21-1984, § 2; Res. No. 1993-06-10, § 2, 6-10-1993) Sec. 42-29. - Charges for initial water and sewer service. Each consumer subscribing to use the water and sewer service of the city shall pay a connection fee to be determined by the city council from time to time, times the number of connections desired for water service and a connection fee to be established by city council from time to time, times the number of connections desired for sewer service, for residential connections and commercial connections that do not require special equipment for piping other than the same as used for residential connections. For commercial connections requiring special equipment, the cost of the equipment and/or piping and labor will be added to the fee. (Ord. No. 101A, § 3, 10-10-1977; Ord. of 11-14-1977, § 3; Ord. No. 1984-02-21, § 3, 2-21-1984; Ord. of 2-21-1984, § 3; Res. No. 1991-08-12, § 3, 8-12-1991; Res. No. 9-1-84, 11-11-1996) Sec. 42-30. - Minimum charges. The minimum charge, as provided in the rate schedule, shall be made for such connection subscribed for. Water furnished for a given lot shall be used on that lot only and, except for fire protection, the city shall not under any condition furnish water free of charge to anyone. (Ord. No. 101A, § 4, 10-10-1977; Ord. No. 1984-02-21, § 4, 2-21-1984; Ord. of 2-21-1984, § 4) Sec. 42-31. - City's responsibility and liability. The city shall run a service line from its distribution line to the property line where the distribution line exists or is to be constructed, and runs immediately adjacent and parallel to the property to be served. No service charge, other than the connection fee referred to in section 42-29, will be made for a five-eighths inch by three-fourths inch meter. A proportionately greater charge than the connection fee in section 42-29 will be made for a meter of larger dimensions. (1) The city may make connections to serve other properties not adjacent to its lines upon payment of reasonable costs for the extensions of its distribution lines as may be required to render such service. (2) The city may install its meter at or near the property line or, at the city's option, on the consumer's property within three feet of the property line. (3) The city reserves the right to refuse service unless the consumer's lines or piping are installed in such a manner as to prevent cross-connections or back-flow. (4) Under normal conditions the consumer will be notified of any anticipated interruptions of service by the city. (Ord. No. 101A, § 5, 10-10-1977; Ord. No. 1984-02-21, § 5, 2-21-1984; Ord. of 2-21-1984, § 5) Sec. 42-32. - Consumer's responsibility and liability. Water furnished by the city shall be used for consumption by the consumer, members of his household and employees only. The consumer shall not sell water to any other person or permit any other person to use said water. Water shall not be used for irrigation, fire protection, or other purposes, except when water is available in sufficient quantity without interfering with the regular domestic consumption in the area served. Disregard for this rule shall be sufficient cause for refusal and/or discontinuance of service. (1) Where a meter or meter box is placed on the premises of a consumer, a suitable place shall be provided by the consumer therefor, unobstructed and accessible at all times to the meter reader. (2) The consumer shall furnish and maintain a private cut-off valve on the consumer's side of the meter. (3) The consumer's piping and apparatus shall be installed and maintained by the consumer at the consumer's expense, in a safe and efficient manner, and in accordance with the sanitary regulations of the state health department. (4) In order to be received as a consumer and entitled to receive water from the city's water system, all applicants must offer proof that any private wells located on their property are not physically connected to the lines of the city's water system, and all applicants, by becoming consumers of the city, covenant and agree that so long as they continue to be consumers of the city they will not permit the connection of any private wells on their property to the city's water system. (Ord. No. 101A, § 6, 10-10-1977; Ord. No. 1984-02-21, § 6, 2-21-1984; Ord. of 2-21-1984, § 6) Sec. 42-33. - Access to premises and extensions of system. (a) Duly authorized agents of the city shall have access at all hours to the premises of the consumer for the purpose of installing or removing city property, inspecting piping, reading and testing meters, or for any other purposes in connection with the water service and its facilities, and the sewer service and its facilities. (b) Extensions to the system shall be made only when the consumer shall grant or convey, or shall cause to be granted or conveyed, to the city a permanent easement of right-of-way across any property traversed by the water and sewer lines. (Ord. No. 101A, § 7, 10-10-1977; Ord. No. 1984-02-21, § 7, 2-21-1984; Ord. of 2-21-1984, § 7) Sec. 42-34. - Change of occupancy. Not less than three days' notice must be given, in person or in writing, at the city hall, to discontinue water and sewer service or to change occupancy. The outgoing party shall be responsible for all water consumed up to the time of departure or the time specified for departure, whichever period is longer. The new occupant shall apply for water service within 48 hours after occupying the premises, and failure to do so will make him liable for paying for the water consumed since the last meter reading. (Ord. No. 101A, § 8, 10-10-1977; Ord. No. 1984-02-21, § 8, 2-21-1984; Ord. of 2-21-1984, § 8) Sec. 42-35. - Meter reading; billing; connection. Bills to customers for water and sewer service shall be mailed out on such day or days of each month as may be determined as desirable by the city. Bills shall be paid at the city hall, and a failure to receive bills or notices shall not prevent such bills from becoming delinquent nor relieve the consumer from payment of same. The failure of water and/or sewer users to pay charges duly imposed shall result in the automatic imposition of the following penalties: (1) Nonpayment within 20 days from the due date will be subject to a penalty of ten percent of the delinquent account. (2) Nonpayment within 40 days from the date due will result in the water being shut off from the water user's property. (3) Nonpayment for 60 days after the original due date will allow the city, in addition to all other rights and remedies, to terminate agreement, and in such event, the water user shall not be entitled to receive, nor the city obligated to supply, any water under this agreement. Service disconnected for nonpayment of this bill will be restored only after bills are paid in full, such security deposit as may be required by the mayor and council is made, and a service charge to be determined by the city council, from time to time, paid for each meter reconnected. (Ord. No. 101A, § 9, 10-10-1977; Ord. No. 1984-02-21, § 9, 2-21-1984; Ord. of 2-21-1984, § 9) Sec. 42-36. - Suspension of service. When water and sewer service is discontinued and all bills paid, the security deposit shall be refunded to the consumer by the city. (1) Upon discontinuance of service for nonpayment of bills, the security deposit will be applied by the city toward settlement of the account. Any balance will be refunded to the consumer; however, if the security deposit is insufficient to cover the bill, the city may proceed to collect the balance in the usual way provided by law for collection of debts. (2) The city reserves the right to discontinue its service without notice for the following additional reasons: a. To prevent fraud or abuse. b. Consumer's willful disregard of the city's rules. c. Emergency repairs. d. Insufficiency of water supply due to circumstances beyond the city's control. e. Legal processes. f. Direction of public authorities. g. Strike, riot, fire, flood, or unavoidable accident. (Ord. No. 101A, § 10, 10-10-1977; Ord. No. 1984-02-21, § 10, 2-21-1984; Ord. of 2-21-1984, § 10) Sec. 42-37. - Complaints; adjustments. If the consumer believes his bill to be in error, he shall present his claim, in person, at the city hall before the bill becomes delinquent. Such claim, if made after the bill has become delinquent, shall not be effective in preventing discontinuance of service as heretofore provided. The consumer may pay such bill under protest and said payment shall not prejudice his claim. (1) The city will make a special water meter reading at the request of a consumer for a fee to be determined by the city council, from time to time; provided, however, that if such special reading discloses that the meter was over-read, no charge will be made. (2) Water meters will be tested at the request of the consumer upon payment to the city of the actual costs of making the test; provided, however, that if the meter is found to over-register beyond three percent of the correct volume, no charge will be made. (3) If the seal of a meter is broken by other than the city's representative or if the meter fails to register correctly or is stopped for any cause, the consumer shall pay an amount estimated from the record of his previous bills and/or from other proper data. (Ord. No. 101A, § 11, 10-10-1977; Ord. of 11-14-1977, § 11(a); Ord. No. 1984-02-21, § 10, 2-21-1984; Ord. of 2-21-1984, § 11) Sec. 42-38. - Mandatory time limitation. All existing residences, businesses and industries within 200 feet of the sewer service, which have indoor plumbing facilities, are required to connect to the central sewer system within 60 days after service is available. All new construction is required to utilize the central sewer system. (Ord. No. 1984-02-21, § 12, 2-21-1984; Ord. of 2-21-1984, § 12) Secs. 42-39—42-64. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - PUBLIC AND PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL DIVISION 1. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 42-65. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: BOD (biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter. Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five feet outside the inner face of the building wall. Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. Garbage means solid wastes from the preparation, cooking and disposing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of produce. Industrial wastes means the liquid wastes from industrial processes as distinct from sanitary sewage. Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater. pH means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration in moles per liter. Properly shredded garbage means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that have been shredded to such degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch in any dimension. Public sewer means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights, and is controlled by public authority. Sanitary sewer means a sewer which carries sewage, and to which stormwaters, surface waters and groundwaters are not intentionally admitted. Sewage means a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions and industrial establishments, together with such groundwaters, surface waters, and stormwaters as may be present. Sewage treatment plant means any arrangement of devices and structures or lagoons used for treating sewage presently owned or afterward acquired by said city. Sewer means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. Sewerage works means all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating and disposing of sewage. Slug flow means any discharge of wastewater which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds, for any period of duration longer than 15 minutes, more than five times the average 24-hour concentration of flows during normal operation and shall adversely affect the collection system and/or performance of the wastewater facility. Storm sewer or storm drain means a sewer which carries stormwaters and surface waters and drainage, but excludes sewage and polluted industrial wastes. Superintendent means the superintendent or manager of the sewerage works of the city, or his authorized deputy, agent or representative, as designated by the mayor and city council. Suspended solids means solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in, water, sewage, or other liquids, and which are removable by laboratory filtering. Watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, §§ 1-1—19-1) Secs. 42-66—42-88. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS
Sec. 42-89. - Deposit of objectionable wastes. It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be placed or deposited, in any unsanitary manner upon public or private property within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of said city, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 1-2) Sec. 42-90. - Discharge of untreated waters. It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of said city, any sanitary sewage, industrial wastes, or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent provisions of this article. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 2-2) Sec. 42-91. - Construction of certain facilities. Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 3-2) Sec. 42-92. - Connection required. The owners of all houses, buildings, or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes within the corporate limits of the city, and located within 300 feet of a line of public sanitary sewer now in existence or after constructed to which such houses, buildings or properties may be connected so that sewage will flow therefrom and into such sewer line by gravity, are hereby required at their own expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein and to connect such facilities directly with said lines of public sanitary sewer in accordance with the provisions of this article within 60 days after the date of official notice so to do. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 4-2; Ord. No. 10-8-84, § 4-2, 11-14-2007) Secs. 42-93—42-112. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL
Sec. 42-113. - Connection required. Where a public sanitary sewer is not available under the provisions of section 42-92, the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of this article. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 1-3) Sec. 42-114. - Permit and inspection fee. Before commencement of construction of a private sewage disposal system, the owner shall first obtain a written permit signed by the superintendent. The application for such permit shall be made on a form furnished by the city, which the applicant shall supplement by any plans, specifications and other information as are deemed necessary by the superintendent. A permit and the inspection fee as determined by the city shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 2-3) Sec. 42-115. - Inspection by superintendent. A permit for a private sewage disposal system shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the superintendent. He shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of construction and, in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify the superintendent when the work is ready for final inspection and before any underground portions are covered. The inspection shall be made within 72 hours of the receipt of notice by the superintendent. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 3-3) Sec. 42-116. - System to comply with state department of natural resources, environmental protection division. The type, capacities, location and layout of a private sewage disposal system shall comply with all recommendations of the department of natural resources, environmental protection division. No permit shall be issued for any private sewage disposal system employing subsurface soil absorption facilities where the area of the lot is less than 20,000 square feet. No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any public sewer or natural outlet. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 4-3) Sec. 42-117. - Connection to public sewer when available. At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private sewage disposal system, as provided in section 42-92, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this chapter, and any septic tanks, cesspools and similar private sewage disposal facilities shall be abandoned and filled with suitable material. However, from the date a public sewer becomes available to the property, the property owners shall pay to the city the minimum sewer charge as determined by the city. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 5-3) Sec. 42-118. - Maintenance of facilities. The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, at no expense to the city. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 6-3) Sec. 42-119. - Effect of provisions of article. No statement contained in this article shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the health officer. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 7-3) Secs. 42-120—42-136. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS
Sec. 42-137. - Disturbing sewers or appurtenances. No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter or disturb any public sewer or appurtenances thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the superintendent. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 1-4) Sec. 42-138. - Permits generally; inspection fee. There shall be two classes of building sewer permits: for residential and commercial service, and for service to establishments producing industrial wastes. In either case, the owner or his agent shall make application on a special form furnished by the city. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the superintendent. A permit and inspection fee in an amount determined by the city for a residential or commercial building sewer permit and a permit and inspection fee in an amount determined by the city for an industrial building sewer permit shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 2-4) Sec. 42-139. - Cost of connection to be borne by owner. All cost and expense incident to the connection of the building sewer from the owner's building to the city property line shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may be directly or indirectly occasioned by the connection of the building sewer. Any connection from the city property line into the public sewer shall be made by the city, for which the owner shall pay the city a standard sewer tap fee in an amount determined by the city for residential taps, and in an amount determined by the city for commercial taps. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 3-4) Sec. 42-140. - Independent sewer to be provided for every building; exception. A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building; except that where one building stands at the rear of another or an interior lot, and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard, or driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 4-4) Sec. 42-141. - Use of old sewers. Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings when they are found, on examination and test by the superintendent, to meet all requirements of this article. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 5-4) Sec. 42-142. - Materials and specifications. The building sewer shall be cast iron pipe, ASTM specification A74; vitrified clay sewer pipe, ASTM specification C13; concrete sewer pipe, ASTM specification C14; or PVC sewer pipe, ASTM specification D3034. Joints shall be tight and waterproof. Any part of the building sewer that is located within ten feet of a water service shall be constructed of cast iron soil pipe with leaded joints. Cast iron pipe with leaded joints may be required by the superintendent where the building sewer is exposed to damage by tree roots. If installed in filled or unstable ground, the building sewer shall be of cast iron soil pipe, except that nonmetallic material may be accepted if laid on a suitable concrete bed or cradle as approved by the superintendent. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 6-4) Sec. 42-143. - Size and slope. The size and slope of the building sewer shall be subject to the approval of the superintendent, but in no event shall the diameter be less than four inches. The slope of such four-inch pipe shall not be less than one-eighth of an inch per foot. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 7-4) Sec. 42-144. - Elevation and grade. Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. No building sewer shall be laid parallel to or within three feet of any bearing wall, which might thereby be weakened. The building sewer shall be laid at a uniform grade and in straight alignment insofar as possible. Changes in direction shall be made only with properly curved pipes and fittings. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 8-4) Sec. 42-145. - Gravity flow. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such drain shall be lifted by approved artificial means and discharged to the building sewer. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 9-4) Sec. 42-146. - Open trench excavation. All excavations required for the installation of a building sewer shall be open trench work unless otherwise approved by the superintendent. Pipe laying and back-fill shall be performed in accordance with ASTM specification C12; except that no back-fill shall be placed until the work has been inspected. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 10-4) Sec. 42-147. - Joints. (a) All joints and connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Cast iron pipe joints shall be firmly placed with oakum or hemp and filled with molten lead, federal specification QQL-156, not less than one inch deep. Lead shall be run in one pouring and calked tight. No paint, varnish or other coatings shall be permitted on the joint varnish nor shall other coatings be permitted on the joint material until after the joint has been tested and approved. Rubber joint cast iron pipe may be used as an alternate. (b) All joints in vitrified clay or concrete pipe or between such pipe and metals shall be made with approved hot-pouring jointing material, as specified below or by using rubber gaskets or preformed, factory-applied couplings having resilient properties in accordance with ASTM specification C443-59T for concrete pipe and ASTM specification C425-64 for vitrified clay pipe, or the latest revisions thereof. (c) Material for hot-poured joints shall not soften sufficiently to destroy the effectiveness of the joint when subjected to a temperature of 160 degrees Fahrenheit, and not be soluble in any of the wastes carried by the drainage system. The joint shall first be caulked tight with jute, hemp, or similar approved material. (d) All PVC joints shall be bell and spigot, coupling with gasket, or solvent weld coupling and shall conform to the latest ASTM specification D3034 or D3033. All joints shall be watertight and gastight. (e) Other jointing materials and methods may be used only by approval of the superintendent. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 11-4) Sec. 42-148. - Location. The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall be made at the "Y" branch, if such branch is available at a suitable location. If the public sewer is 12 inches in diameter or less, and no properly-located "Y" branch is available, the city shall install a "Y" branch in the public sewer at the location specified by the superintendent. Where the public sewer is greater than 12 inches in diameter, and no properly-located "Y" is available, a neat hole may be cut into the public sewer to receive the building sewer, which entry is in the downstream direction at an angle of about 45 degrees. A 45-degree "ell" may be used to make such connection, with the spigot end cut so as not to extend past the inner surface of the public sewer. The invert of the building sewer at the point of connection shall be at the same or at a higher elevation than the invert of the public sewer. A smooth, neat joint shall be made, and the connection made secure and watertight by encasement in concrete. Special fittings may be used for the connection only when approved by the superintendent. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 12-4) Sec. 42-149. - Inspection. The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the superintendent when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 13-4) Sec. 42-150. - Excavations to be properly guarded. All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 14-4) Secs. 42-151—42-168. - Reserved. DIVISION 5. - USE OF THE PUBLIC SEWER REGULATED
Sec. 42-169. - Waters prohibited. No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, ground water, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, cooling water or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 1-5) Sec. 42-170. - Discharge of unpolluted process waters. Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the superintendent. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged upon approval of the superintendent, to a storm sewer or natural outlet. The industry must procure a NPDES permit from the state environmental protection division before discharge of cooling water or unpolluted process water will be allowed. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 2-5) Sec. 42-171. - Regulations of discharges. Except as hereinafter provided, no person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described waters or wastes to any public sewer: (1) Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than 150 degrees Fahrenheit at point of discharge or causing the treatment plant influent wastewater temperature to exceed 40 degrees Celsius (104 degrees Fahrenheit). (2) Any water or waste which may contain more than 100 milligrams per liter of fat, oil or greases. (3) Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas. (4) Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. (5) Any ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, paunch manure, or any other solid or viscous substance capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers or other interference with the proper operation of the sewage works. (6) Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or higher than 9.0, or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment and personnel of the sewerage works. (7) Any waters or wastes containing a toxic or poisonous substance in sufficient quantity to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals, or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant. (8) Any waters or wastes containing suspended solids of such character and quantity that unusual attention or expense is required to handle such materials at the sewage treatment plant. (9) Any noxious or malodorous gas or substance capable of becoming a public nuisance. (10) Any waters or wastes containing a toxic or poisonous substance such as plating or heat treatment wastes in sufficient quantity to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment or to create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant. (11) Any slug flow of wastewater quantity or constituent as defined in section 42-65. (12) Any heavy metals as follows: a. Cyanide greater than one part per million, as CN. b. Hexavalent chromium greater than one part per million. c. Trivalent chromium greater than ten parts per million. d. Copper greater than one part per million. e. Nickel greater than one part per million. f. Cadmium greater than one part per million. g. Zinc greater than one part per million. h. Phenols greater than 12 parts per million. i. Iron greater than five parts per million. j. Tin greater than one part per million. (13) Radioactive wastes greater than the allowable release as specified by current United States Bureau of Standards. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 3-5) Sec. 42-172. - Prohibition of excess oxygen demanding and excessive suspended solids discharge. (a) The admission into the public sewers of any waters or wastes having: (1) A five-day biochemical oxygen demand greater than 300 milligrams per liter; (2) A chemical oxygen demand (COD) greater than 600 milligrams per liter; (3) More than 350 milligrams per liter of suspended solids; or (4) Any quantity of substances having the characteristics described in section 42-171; shall be prohibited from discharge without preliminary treatment. (b) The owner shall provide, at his expense, such preliminary treatment as may be necessary to: (1) Reduce the biochemical oxygen demand to 300 milligrams per liter and the chemical oxygen demand to 600 milligrams per liter and the suspended solids to 350 milligrams per liter; (2) Reduce objectionable characteristics or constituents to within the maximum limits provided for in section 42-171; or (3) Control the quantities and rates of discharge of such waters or wastes. Plans, specifications and any other pertinent information relating to proposed preliminary treatment facilities shall be submitted for the approval of the superintendent, and no construction of such facilities shall be commenced until said approval is obtained in writing. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 4-5) Sec. 42-173. - Grease, oil and sand interceptors—Required. Grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the superintendent, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand and other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the superintendent and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. Grease and oil interceptors shall be constructed of impervious materials capable of withstanding abrupt and extreme changes in temperature. They shall be of substantial construction, watertight, and equipped with easily removable covers which, when bolted in place, shall be gastight and watertight. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 5-5) Sec. 42-174. - Same—Maintenance. Where installed, all grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be maintained by the owner, at his expense, in continuously efficient operation at all times. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 6-5) Sec. 42-175. - Same—Maintenance of facilities. Where preliminary treatment facilities are provided for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner, at his expense. (Ord. of 10-8-1984, § 7-5) Sec. 42-176. - Control manholes—Required. When required by the superintendent, the owner of any property served by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the wastes.
